text:
Excellent, moist and delicious, made exactly as shown. 
Be aware that the large number of chocolate chips used in the batter may prevent the testing toothpick from EVER coming out "clean", even after 55 minutes or more of baking. I took mine out at 60 min -- thankfully just before it started to burn on top! 
I used the "Satiny Chocolate Glaze" recipe (also on allrecipes.com) for the icing and it too was easy to make and wonderful. This cake was a big hit at the party I took it to and this recipe has become the go-to chocolate cake in my house.
Another hint: Use Wilton Cake Release on your Bundt pan to assure that it will come out easily.

I did not stray from this recipe. It turned out absolutely amazing. My boyfriend and my mom were in shock. It was perfect. This will forever be my go-to chocolate cake. text:
For an easy delicious presentation I buttered my Bundt pan and sprinkled very finely chopped walnuts on the entire pan, getting as much to stick as I could. (Only the finest pieces will stick. A nut mill works fine.) Then I poured in my batter and sprinkled a few more nuts on top. It turned out beautiful! The butter gives the cake a nice shine (unlike shortening) and the toasted nuts not only look good but also complement the flavor of this rich chocolate cake.

text:
Excellent and very easy. If you add mini chocolate chips the toothpick test really isn't helpful - it will come out gooey with melted chocolate even if the cake is finished. Know your oven, trust the time and as long as the top is springy you'll be good. Rather than a glaze I combined this with a homemade amaretto whipped cream (heavy whipping cream + a dash of amaretto liqueur or almond extract   + 1 TBS of confectioner's sugar + tsp cream of tartar for stiffness). It was a nice complement.

country:

text:
Editing my previous review, because I've used this recipe for a few years now with many variations.  I just love that I can switch the pudding and cake mixes and end up with something completely different, yet just as wonderful.
My favorites are 1. triple chocolate fudge cake mix with chocolate pudding and mini milk chocolate chips and 2. white cake mix with white chocolate pudding mix and white chocolate chips.  I have turned a few of the white chocolate ones into rainbow cakes for fun.  Tomorrow, I'll make a butterscotch variant!
The mini chips are so much better than full chips.  Unfortunately, mini chips only come in milk chocolate, so I'll chop up the full chips in other flavors if I'm not feeling super lazy.
Before this recipe, I always kept away from cake mixes.  This recipe has taught me that, with a little tinkering, even boxed mixes can taste homemade.

text:
I'll admit that I was concerned about making this cake because I have a recipe off of this site that I always use that is made from scratch.  BUT I made this and well, it was worth trying.  I did follow other reviewers suggestions and cut the oil, added milk and used less chocolate chips than called for.  I also left the cake in the pan for 1 1/2 hours as directed.  This cake is dark, moist and oh so so good!  People will NEVER know that it is an "altered" box mix.  I made the chocolate glaze that others suggested and it just took it over the top.  I tasted the cake after I took it out of the pan and I still wasn't convinced but after letting the cake sit overnight and tasting it the next day, all I can say is YUM!  I will make this cake again and I will experiment with additional flavors.

text:
If you really want to make it CHOCOLATE, get the double chocolate cake mix with pudding already in it and mix as directed.  Add a large double chocolate instant pudding mix.  Add mini chocolate chips.  Bake in a sheet pan as directed.  When cooking time is finished, remove from oven, poke holes in top of cake and pour (drizzle) an entire can of real chocolate syrup on top.  Serve hot with ice cream.  I call Killer Chocolate Cake.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made 4 dozen cupcakes with this recipe for my son's birthday party, and at least 10 different people came up to tell me how amazing they were. Some tips for making Too Much Chocolate Cupcakes: Each recipe yields about 2 dozen cupcakes, and the recipe doubles very easily. Bake every dozen at 350 for 24 minutes. Let the cupcakes rest in the cupcake pans until slightly cool before removing. Do not use double weight, waxed cupcake liners (which is what I used to make the cupcakes). The amount of oil in the recipe makes the cake super moist but also a bit oily, which made the liners come apart from the actual cake after being kept overnight. You're better off using regular, thin cupcake liners, which stick to the cakes better. Also, I accidentally made the marshmallow frosting that went on top of the cupcakes a tiny bit salty (the recipe I used called for "pinches of salt" and I might have added a pinch too much), but many of my guests said they loved how the slightly salty icing complemented the sweet cake. So if you're making an icing try making it a bit saltier than you normally would. Thanks again to Denise for this wonderful recipe!

text:
This recipe is ALL over the blogging world... and now I know why! I typically make my cakes from scratch, but found that doesn't always yield the perfect results when I need to make the cake in the Pampered Chef Batter Bowl for barbie cakes. So, I broke down and make this recipe after my sister had great success with it. Deliciously moist and wonderful - baked up beautifully! I baked at 350 for about 75 minutes for the batter bowl cakes, then used the recipe again in two 8" round pans. This gave me a couple extra inches to plunge the (plastic-wrapped) barbie into the cake without taking drastic measures like chopping offer her legs (as some people have reportedly done...really).  So, two barbie cakes used 3 batches of this recipe. A keeper. At least for Barbie cakes.

text:
made this for the bf and my cousins, they loved it! Its a good base to build on or substitute with your available ingredients. For me the changes i made were - yoghurt instead of sour cream, and followed the reviews to half the oil (i used 100ml) and added about 100ml milk. I used only the 3.9oz pudding pack, strong coffee instead of water and tossed in about 2 heaping Tbsp of cocoa for a stronger chocolate taste. Cooked for way longer than 55mins, 1.5 hrs instead.

text:
This has become my friends and families FAVORITE cake.  I make it according to the recipe, and don't be fooled by the thick batter, it comes out moist and delicious everytime.  I top it the with the Satiny Glaze found on this site and sprinkle some powder sugar and walnuts on top.  It always gets rave reviews. Some reviews have stated that the edges are crispy - I use a dark bundt pan and decrease the oven temp to 325.  It seems the lower temp eliminates that problem.   THIS IS A MUST MAKE CAKE.  Chocolate lovers must try it .. YOU'LL LOVE IT.

text:
This cake is delicious...after reading other comments I used 1Stick of butter and 1/4	cup of oil.  I also cooked it at 335 and started checking it every 5 minutes at the 35 to 40 min mark.  You have to watch a chocolate cake so it doesn't taste 'burnt'.  The batter is very thick but cooks up nicely.  Do to smaller cake mixes just reduce the wet ingredients by a fraction to make up for it.  It does not need frosting, as it is plenty sweet.  Add a splash of Grand Marnier if so inclined.   This is a keeper.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
There is no such thing as too much chocolate! This is an absolutely decadent cake! I baked the cake exactly as written. I didn’t have a bundt pan, and baked it in a tube/angel food cake pan instead. I did need to bake it for 10 minutes longer, but I’m not sure if it was because of the pan I used or if my oven temperature may be off. I drizzled over the cake a chocolate glaze flavored with Bailey’s Irish Cream, and everyone was in chocolate heaven! Everyone asked for the recipe, and a few of them went home and made their own with rave reviews. One served it with vanilla ice cream and hot fudge – how yummy does that sound?! Another friend added chopped nuts. Still another made a Black Cherry Chocolate glaze by using the flavored syrup used in coffee and hot chocolate. The variations to go with this cake are many! It is a very moist and dense cake, and worth every calorie! It is a very easy and impressive cake to bake and serve. As for the folks who have problems with the regular sized chocolate chips sinking, just dust them with flour prior to folding into the batter, and they will stay afloat during the baking process. This recipe is a definite keeper!!

text:
Seriously the BEST chocolate cake ever.  I'm not a huge fan, because I think most aren't very moist. This is so moist and so yummy...a friend picked up a piece and ate it right out of her hand with no fork, plate or napkin..like she'd never experienced chocolate cake before!!  I've made it with Devil's Food cake mix, Milk Chocolate cake mix and most recently Chocolate Fudge cake mix...Devil's Food was definitely the best.  If using a dark pan reduce the temp 25 degrees and check for doneness a little under the minimum cooking time.  Doesn't need frosting on top...overkill for sure!  (sprinkle powdered sugar if you must:)

text:
This cake is great!  I use the mini chips because they don't sink to the bottom and stick to the pan.  Also when I make it in a bundt I bake it at 325 for 75 minutes because when I do it at 350 because the batter is so thick the top burns for me.  So lowering the heat and lengthing the time takes care of that.

I have made this cake twice and it has been a hit each time!  People have asked me for the recipe and are shocked to know that it's an adapted cake mix!  I did as a few reviewers suggested and lowered the oil to 1/2 cup and added milk to still add moisture. It worked out great! The cake stayed very moist, even a couple days later! photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has got to be the best semi-homemade cake EVER! I read through the reviews and wanted to try some variations but I didn't have time to make a test version, so I followed the recipe with the exception of using only 3/4 c. oil and mini chocolate chips. Baked in a fancy bundt pan for 55 minutes. I was concerned that it wasn't quite done but it ended up just a tiny bit gooey near the center and everybody raved about it. Just a dusting of powdered sugar on top was perfect. Next time I would cut the oil to 1/2 cup and replace some with homemade applesauce, which is what I always do for my breads (zucchini, banana, etc.). The mini chocolate chips melt so there is no issue of them sinking to the bottom of the pan. I don't know how someone could not love this chocolate heaven if they follow the recipe.

text:
well, it's my nature to tweak recipes so this one was no different. I used a small SF/FF box of chocolate pudding, 1/2c oil and 1/2c applesauce. I only used 1c mini chocolate chips and I tossed them in flour so they wouldn't sink to the bottom. I used Duncan Hines Devils food because in my  humble opinion it's the BEST cake ever ;) 
the cake batter was very thick and I admit I was concerned about that. It baked for 1 hour. IT IS BY FAR THE MOST MOIST AND DELICIOUS CHOCOLATE CAKE EVER.

text:
As far as I know there haven't been any reviews when it comes to making cupcakes with this recipe. Well, I made cupcakes with this yesterday. Jumbo cupcakes. 
They turned out GREAT. 
However, I only baked them for 45 minutes. Any longer and they would have been too done. 
Oh, and while I was baking I completely forgot to put the pudding in. They still turned out moist and delicious. I baked them for a bake sale and they were gone in no time. 
So, next time I make these I'll remember the pudding. I can't wait to see how they turn out. I can't imagine these being any more delicious.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
No such thing as too much chocolate in my book, but wow this cake will definitely satisfy your chocolate cravings.  I made it the first time exactly as stated & loved it, but made a few changes the second time around which I thought made it better:  To reduce the fat & because it is a tad bit greasy I used 1/2 cup of unsweetened apple sauce & 1/2 cup oil, I also used reduced fat sour cream. The one thing that I did that I think made the biggest difference...I substituted 1/2 cup of strong coffee for the 1/2 cup of water. It gives the cake an extra added dimension of richness, and also made it taste entirely homemade, you don't get any of that subtle out of the box cake flavor that I think the recipe has a bit of when you make it exactly as written.  Fantastic over all though, regardless of if you tweek it or not. Thanx Denise!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome cake! After a few shots I finally figured out my combo: substituted Starbucks Mocha Frappaccino (in the glass jar at the store) for the water, used 1/2 cup oil and 1/3 cup milk instead, used 1 1/2 cups chocolate chips instead, and finally added a teaspoon of vanilla extract. I also baked it at 350 for the first 40 minutes and then turned it down to 300 for the last 15 minutes. I let it cool for an hour and then topped it with a cream cheese glaze (Mix 4 ounces cream cheese, 1 tablespoon butter, 2 cups confectioner's sugar, 1 teaspoon vanilla extract, and 1 tablespoon milk. Heat in microwave in 15 second intervals until smooth.)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love, love chocolate. Let's get that out of the way right now.  That being said, as many other reviewers said, this cake is dense, and for me, I've realized I'd rather have a light and airy cake.  In the future, if I want dense, I'll make brownies or fudge.  As a huge chocolate lover, I can't believe I'm going to say this, but I think it actually just may have just have been......too....much....chocolate...cake.  

I used a Duncan Hines fudge cake mix, and followed the recipe exactly.  Mine wasn't all that moist, which was surprising, given the amount of reviews raving about the moistness of the cake.
 I frosted it with the satiny chocolate glaze from this site, so to be fair it may have made a better pairing with some sort of cream cheese or other non chocolate frosting.  

If I were to ever use this recipe again, I would definitely try some other pairings, as suggested by some other people - maybe try to give it more depth and flavor by using peanut butter or butterscotch combinations (in the chips and/or a non-fudge cake mix base).

I never imagined how many compliments I would get making this cake.  Everyone who even thought about this cake loved it!!  I ended up having to make it twice in the same week, and once was for my husband who swears he hates cake and chocolate.  I've been getting requests ever since. Modification:  I accidentally left the chocolate chips on the stove when I was preheating and they melted the first time I made this.  I put them in anyway and the cake won raves from my family the second time I made sure I did not melt the chips and the cake was not liked as well.  So ever since I have melted the chips in a double boiler before adding them in and have always have had raves ever since.    Try it!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cake was a knockout and so incredibly warm, gooey, and moist... the ideal chocolate cake really! I made this using a petite loaf pan (with a little bit leftover, which I separated into another muffin pan). I left the temp at 350 but cut the baking time to about 45 mins.  The little loafs turned out perfectly, and just the right size to serve as individual desserts for our guests.  I plated them straight from the oven while still piping hot, then added a generous scoop of ice cream on the side (we had sweet mint chocolate chip and english toffee caramel, both were delicious in combination with the cake).  Our friends devoured it!!  One additional note, I cut the oil down to 2/3 cup and used lowfat sour cream. I was a bit worried in the beginning because the batter seemed awfully spongy & goopy and not at all like typical cake batter consistency, but after whipping them out of the oven... they turned out beautifully! You will not regret making this recipe.

text:
Fabulous cake and SO EASY to make!  And, I say that as someone who isn't much into baking.  It's also highly customizable, which I love!  Just trade out for different flavors of cake mix, pudding mix, and chips/morsels.  Works great with yellow cake, butterscotch pudding & butterscotch morsels.  Also with lemon cake, lemon pudding and white chocolate chips.  My favorite combinations so far are 1) spice cake mix, butterscotch pudding mix & (seasonal) pumpkin flavored chips and 2) chocolate cake mix, pistachio pudding mix, and mint flavored chips!  See?  FABULOUS! Just walk down the baking aisle and see which combos sound good together!

text:
I hate to be a spoil sport on this cake... I really, really wanted to like it... but it just did not do it for me. I followed the directions to the t... the only thing I changed was subbing the water for coffee which is what I generally do in all of my chocolate cake recipes...and what I got was a cake with a somewhat crisp outside and and the inside was the consistency of a semi cooked brownie... I baked the cake in a bundt for only 50 mins as recommended by others and quickly removed it from the oven... and let it cool for an hour so it could easily slide out of the pan... It did that just fine.. but once placed on the cake plate the cake began to sag on one side... more than likely because of the chocolate chips/sour cream/oil mixture making it somewhat too moist. I will continue to use the Black Magic Cake Recipe from this site instead... But thank you for the recipe though. Happy Baking!

I took the advice of alot of reviewers and substituted applesauce for olive oil, and low fat sourcream.  The taste was delicious, not too sweet, which is what my family likes. However, I found the texture to be extremely dense- almost like that of a brownie.  I was planning to make it into a 2 tiered, fondant-covered cake, and all the while I was crumb-coating, I felt like I was coating two big brownies!  When I make this recipe again, I will keep to a 13x9 pan, or a bundt pan. Otherwise, this was yummy!

text:
This recipe is delicious just as Denise submitted it...obviously as it has over 2,000 good reviews and 58,000 people have saved it. Having made this numerous times, I make the following changes that my family seems to enjoy best.  I use a SMALL (3.9 oz.) box instant chocolate pudding, substitute 1/2 cup brewed coffee in place of water, & add only 1 cup mini chocolate chips. I also find that adding 1/2 tsp. vanilla & 1/4 tsp. almond extract helps eliminate the "cake Mix' taste. These changes seem to make it a little less "chocolately"..although it IS called Too Much Chocolate cake :)

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cake is awesome! I had to change things a little bit based on what I had on hand. It was so good, I think next time I will stick to the changes I made. I used a triple chocolate fudge cake mix, a 3 oz box of chocolate pudding, only had two eggs- so replaced the other two with 1/2 cup vanilla yogurt, reduced water to 1/4 cup, and just added a handful of milk chocolate chips. Topped with "Satiny Chocolate Glaze", but that part wasn't great, next time will try a different glaze, one that is actually a glaze. Recipe purists will probably complain that this isn't even the same recipe, but I just wanted to share in case someone else was in a pinch and didn't have all the ingredients. A great cake... even though there is no such thing as "too much" chocolate!

text:
This was a phenomenon cake recipe!  I was a little concerned when making it because it was very thick - there was no "pouring" it into the cake pans.  However, it came out beautifully.  It was rich and moist.  I used two 9 inch cake pans (done after 40 minutes).  While this may be chocolately enough on its own, my husband is a choco-holic, so I iced it with chocolate mousse (I used the chocolate mousse cake IV recipe on this website).  I cut each cake in half length-wise, and layered the mousse in between the four layers.  My husband and co-workers absolutely loved it.  This is going to be my go-to cake recipe for now on.

text:
Tried this "as is" for my birthday in February and was definitely not disappointed! Scrumptious from first to last bite. But there's more: I just snuck a small piece from the underside of a second cake I made after modifying this recipe, and it's just as good, even though it's not chocolate! I got the idea because St. Patrick's Day is tomorrow. I used an 18.25-oz. package of classic white cake mix and two small (3.4-oz) packages of pistachio instant pudding mix, and I omitted the chocolate chips entirely. What I got was a deliciously smooth, lightly pistachio-flavored cake, in a gorgeous light spring green color! It's terrific right now, while it's still warm in the bundt pan, but I think it's going to be even better after it cools ... I can't wait! Thanks for sharing this Denise! I will make this again and again and again. Update: The pistachio version was gone in two days, and just my hubby and I were eating it. Piggies, aren't we? LOL

All I can say is AMAZING!  I took another reviewer's idea and used peanut butter chips instead of chocolate chips.  My husband said it tasted like a big brownie with a hint of peanut butter.  I even made it slightly healthier by using reduced fat sour cream, two eggs and two egg whites, and applesauce instead of the vegetable oil.  It was incredibly rich and moist, will definitely be making this again.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/113294.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this several times.  What a fantastic and quick recipe to throw together.  This is a doctored cake mix but tastes like a completely homemade cake.  When I need a cake or cupcakes in a hurry, this is the recipe I turn to.  I pretty much follow the recipe to a "T" BUT, for a more intense chocolate flavor, replace that 1/2 cup warm water with a 1/2 cup strong coffee or even espresso.  That really brings it over the top.  I rarely bake this cake in a bundt or tube pan.  I usually make it in cupcake or layer cake pans. I have even baked this recipe in mini loaf pans.  It's wonderful with just powdered sugar sprinkled over it after baking, or with a rich chocolate glaze or ganache or with a silky chocolate frosting. But my favorite way is with a nice sweet white buttercream icing.  I bet it would be delicious with a peanut butter icing also.  One thing to mention though, after mixing all the ingredients together, sometimes my cake batter tends to look greasy (but not other times?? not sure why) but the cake always ends up perfect after baking it.

This receipe is so delicious. Mini chocolate chips work best because they don't sink to the bottom and they melt into every bite! To top off this cake.. I take a plastic container of chocolate frosting (can be Pillsbury, Betty Crocker, or any other frosting)-microwave for about one minute and pour over the cake while in the baking dish. So delicious. Tastes delicious while warm and with vanilla ice cream.

text:
55 minutes is waaaaaay to long to be baking this cake..... in a 9x12 glass pan anyway. I'm not sure if it's correct for a bundt cake. I only put that sucker in for 45 mins and my cake was burned. All that oil also made it too oily. Boooo! Luckily, I bought extra ingredients just in case. Second time around, I baked for however long the box told me to, reduced the oil to 1/2 a cup, and perfection! Goes AMAZING with the German Chocolate Cake Frosting II from this site. The frosting and cake can still be warm when adding the frosting. BIG time saver!

It TOTALLY lived up to its excellent rating on this site. Scrumptious cake!!! I just made the following modifications: Used 1/2 cup oil and 1/3 cup milk (instead of 1 cup oil), Added only 1.25 cup of chocolate chips, Used mini chips instead of regular size so they can melt easier. I used Pillsbury Super Moist cake mix (which already has a cup of pudding in it) with a 3.9 oz pack of pudding. I had to serve it the next day so microwaved the slices for 15 seconds and served with Vanilla icecream. It was OUT OF THIS WORLD DELICIOUS! Thank you so much for the recipe! :)

text:
This basic recipe works in other flavors as well! Try lemon cake mix with lemon pudding and white choc chips, white cake with vanilla pudding and chips, endless possibilities. Chocolate fudge cake mix with choclate fudge pudding and dark chocolate chips is superb! This recipe is almost exactly the same as one from the Kraft site, I usually cut the oil to 3/4 cup. I decorate cakes and I always use this recipe because it is easy to do in 2 round pans, 9x13, tube pan (increase cooking time), or cupcakes. It is nice and moist but still on the heavy side so it's easy to frost and holds together well when layered and sliced, doesn't crumble like some scratch cakes do. Freezes well, I have several in my freezer waiting to be decorated...

country:
None
text:
Despite the fact that this is one of THE most celebrated recipes on this site, I can't bring myself to give this any more than a 3.  Let me start off by saying that I'm not that much of a cake lover so maybe I'm biased.  But with all the 5-star reviews, I had to try this.  I should have gotten my first warning by the fact that the base of this cake comes from a box.  Sorry, but add all the extras you want, this is nothing more than a dressed up Betty Crocker/Duncan Hines, whatever and it tastes like it.  There was nothing special about it, I didn't feel the sour cream or extra oil added much density to it.  Maybe I should have used two eggs and two egg yolks, not sure but I've tasted 5-star cakes before and this is not one.  If I ordered this in a restaurant, I'd consider it a waste of money.  Because this is a cake mix cake, it's lacking in any real chocolate flavor.  To be honest, there was no depth of flavor at all.  I would definitely recommend using mini chocolate chips.  The regular-sized ones don't sink as someone else suggested but texturally, I think mini chips would work better.  I thought for all the fat in the cake, it lacked moistness and density that I was expecting.  Sorry but won't be making this again.

country:
None
text:
This cake is awesome! I made it exactly as the recipe states. I used regular chocolate chips, not mini ones as someone else suggested and they did not sink to the bottom of the cake at all. In fact, when the cake cooled completely, you get soft chocolate chips with every bit! It was a huge hit with our guests for our daughter's birthday. I made a glaze to top it off, and it was fantastic and didn't add all that much sweetness. If you want the perfect chocolate cake glaze, follow this: 3/4 cup semi-sweet chocolate chips, 3 Tbsp butter, 1 Tbsp light corn syrup, and 1/2 tsp. vanilla. Cook in microwave for 1 minute and then stir until nice and smooth. Spoon over cake.

text:
This was tasty and moist... I used kahlua instead of water to add a little more depth to the flavor- this was good, and next time I'll try coffee.  I used mini chips which I'd highly recommend since they don't sink like full-size chips can, and they get more distributed.  I made cupcakes (about 32) and baked for about 18 minutes.  I frosted with the creamy chocolate frosting recipe on this site- and the combination worked well.  I was a little disappointed today (day after) that the cupcakes aren't more moist, but I may have baked them a minute too long- it's so important not to overbake stuff.  Still, very tasty and will keep this recipe around!

text:
excellent! I made this as a two layer round cake and used whiped cream cheese frosting from this site and plenty of strawberries. First time I followed recipe, second time made a few changes:
Replace water with warm coffee or warm black tea. 
instead of one cup oil use 2/3 cup
use 1 and 1/4 cup sour cream
add 1/4 cup of milk
use mini choc.chips and reduce to 1 cup
Brought this to a social event it was gone in minutes. Everyone kept saying "now that's a cake!!" Great as is and amazing with above changes.

I personally do not care for chocolate cake of any kind, but OMG, this is great!  I made this for the BF's b-day and it was a hit!  He asked next time go without frosting b/c the cake itself was so tasty.
I followed the lower fat suggestions of light sour cream, 1/2c milk and 1/2 oil.  I topped it with the chocolate cheese frosting.  I also cooked it in two 5" springforms at 350 for 45 minutes and they turned out perfect.  There was leftover batter, so I made 6 cupcakes too.
I will absolutely be making this again!

text:
After reading all of the reviews I knew I had to try this recipe. Chocolate can never be bad!!! I am a die hard chocoholic, I love to bake, especially desserts, so this recipe seemed made for me.
The cake was very moist and had a wonderfully decadent texture to it. It looked perfect, tasted good, but like some reviewers, there wasn't a wow factor. It is a good recipe for a boxed cake mix, but those who make their cakes from scratch will know that you can definitely taste the difference between the processed cake mix and that of a scratch batch. I still enjoyed the final product, as did my family, but they are spoiled and prefer home made treats. All in all, it was just a dressed up cake mix.

text:
Followed the recipe except with half as much oil and a third cup of milk as suggested by another reviewer. I made it into a two layer cake with 9-inch pans (340 degrees, somwhere around 45 minutes) and covered it with Special Buttercream Frosting (recipe from this site :) ). The cake was great, delicious, rich, and chocolately; everyone loved it! However, I have to agree with another reviewer, it just tasted like a slightly enhanced cake mix with chocolate chips. The chocolate chips were really the source of the rich chocolately taste; the cake itself was more of a "supporting" taste but it complemented the chocolate really well :) Thanks again!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this cake for my son's birthday, and all I can say is WOW!  No wonder it won a ribbon at the county fair!  I did leave out the chocolate chips, as my son is a "purist" when it comes to his cake (no nuts, chocolate chips or anything chunky at all).  I made it in two 9 inch cake pans, and layered with milk chocolate frosting.  Do NOT make this mistake, as it was too sweet in my opinion.  This cake stands alone, and does not need the "extra" sweetness from the frosting.  That having been said, it was the most moist chocolate cake I have ever made.  In two days, the entire cake was devoured by my sons.  They are already asking for another one!    Thanks for the recipe!

Oh my goodness.  A friend told me he had never tried bundt cake, so I decided to make him one as a just-because present. text:
Chocolate goodness! I have to admit I was hesitant to use a box cake mix but the results were amazing. The cake was rich, moist, easy, quick and very chocolatey.  I made this for my daughter's birthday party and everyone loved it. Everyone was asking me what recipe I used and raved about the taste. I used 1 cup of mini chocolate chips instead of 2 cups and out of purely not reading the recipe correctly I ended up using 2 -(2oz) boxes of instant pudding mix instead of a large box (which I did not have). I baked the cake in a greased metal 9x13" pan for 33 minutes and iced the cake with buttercream frosting (from AR).  A must make again!

country:
None
text:
I have made this cake (and a bunch of other bundt cakes that use box cake mix) a few times and while I always thought they tasted good they weren't great.  Then I took a look at the cake mixes and all of them in my grocery store in NYC were 15.25 oz not 18.25.  So I used my new handy dandy digital scale and redid the math (never my strong suit but my son helped) and holy moly the cake came out perfect!  So be sure to look at the cake mix's net weight and change the amounts accordingly.

text:
My grandmother made this cake for my mother  and her siblings when she was a child. Then, my mom made it for me and mine. Now, 20 years later, my siblings and I still make this cake for special events and holidays. My cousin specifically asked for us to make this cake as his grooms cake at his wedding! There are a couple different things that go into my grandma's recipe (that I won't disclose) but all in all, it's an amazing cake and easy recipe. Little tip: flip your cake right after it comes out of the oven. If you don't, the cake has a tendency to stick and because it's so moist, it'll break apart.

None
text:
Excellent, easy-to-make cake.  I believe I now know why the other reviewer's comments vary about whether to use 1 cup of oil versus only 3/4 cups of oil.  Not all cake mixes are 18.25 ounces.  The cake mix I used was 16.5 ounces, so I used only 3/4 cups of oil (I left everything else the same).  So, in my opinion, let the size of your cake mix determine how much oil to use.  I ended up cooking it for 60 minutes (bundt pan) and it was incredibly moist and done to perfection.

text:
This year I decided to bake my own birthday cake.  I searched for a recipe for a dense, chocolately decadent cake, yet easy to make.  This recipe was a real WINNER! It came through in all ways, my husband I really enjoyed it.  Best of all I loved reading all the reviews, some of them where hilarious! And a lot of them offered great ideas on changing up the combo of flavours, while using the same basic concepts.  Must say - I don't think it's fair to change a recipe, then criticize the outcome...enough said on that ??!  Only thing I was concerned about was the length of time baking, my oven is convection which gets really hot, and we live at a higher altitude, so I tend to watch the temp and time carefully.  I think everyone's oven has its own "personality", which is reflected in a lot of the reviews.  So, If  you are looking for a scrumptious, easy and quick to assemble recipe for a dense chocolate cake this is the one for you,  Bon Appetit!

text:
This cake was everything it promised to be! I followed the receipe exactly except for the following modifications:

1) I used only 1 cup of semi-sweet chocolate chips, because I was afraid 2 cups would overwhelm the flavor of the cake. In my opinion, 1 cup is all you need! 

2) I wanted a more "grown-up" cake, so I substituted the 1/2 cup of water with 1/2 cup of Buffalo Trace Bourdon Cream. It turned out with the perfect overtone of the bourdon cream! I can easily imagine you could replace the water with whiskey, Irish cream, Guinness, ect. 

3) I used Duncan Hines Dark Chocolate Fudge Cake Mix instead of Devil Food. Holy cow it's good!

This cake is sooo good. I've made it a few times and find it pretty forgiving. I used a cake with "pudding in the mix" so didn't add it the first time and it came out great. text:
I rarely take the time to rate recipes, but I've been using this for years and it's ALWAYS a winner. Best results for the least amount of time/effort when you're in a crunch. I also use coffee for water and mini-chips, but I'm sure it's great as-is. I have made this as cupcakes (~30min) and mini cupcakes (~22mins), birthday cakes, mini-loaves, etc. Recipe doubles and triples wonderfully. Cream cheese icing works well if you want to decorate. The ONLY downside is I can't share the recipe--it would ruin my street cred to see boxed mix ingredients. :)

This is so fantastic!  I followed the recipe, using mini-chocolate chips as so many suggested.  This was part of my daughter's birthday cake, and I found it easy to frost and decorate.  When I was mixing the batter, it had this interesting, blob-like consistency that made it so easy to pour.  It rose beautifully in the oven, too.  Because this was for a birthday, I didn't use a bundt cake pan, but rather 2 8x8 square pans.  This cake is moist and chocolatey, and definitely a go-to recipe!

text:
This is my "go to" chocolate cake recipe. I have made it more than 2 dozen times as written.... this is the cake my family (kids, parents, husband, in-laws, friends) want for their birthday. No more store bought cakes for us. This feels special and is SO delicious with chocolate ganache on top. (Melt choc. chips, add cream, a touch of vanilla...stir unit smooth and then pour over cake). I usually use my bundt pan. I usually make homemade vanilla bean ice cream to go with it. Today I am trying rounds, for a tall multi-layer cake for my daughters birthday.

I used to be a "bake from scratch" baker.... or buy it from the store, but this recipe has made making an impressive dessert easy and fast.... and has changed my mind about using cake mixes as a base.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe a zillion times and it is always a hit. I've done it as a bundt cake, as a layer cake and as cupcakes, sometimes with frosting, sometimes with a glaze, sometimes with a dusting of powdered sugar. I topped it with a chocolate almond frosting and won 2nd place at the TN state fair. In response to those who have  complained that their's came out too dry or that baking it at 350 makes the outside "crunchy", I would strongly suggest that you make this cake at least a day before you plan to serve it. In fact, I don't even frost it until the next day. Once it has cooled I either wrap it in plastic or put it into a gallon size ZipLock bag to set overnight. Much like quick breads and muffins, it becomes more moist overtime.

text:
I just made this-according to directions- even though the 2c chocolate chips seemed like too much and I could find a 15.25oz box of cake. This was so unbelievably easy! With the amount of oil it did not stick to the bowl and poured very easily into the pam-sprayed bunt pan. Baked about 45 min. Couple hours later it slipped easily out of the pan onto a plate and I dusted with powdered sugar. Looked great! A+ for ease! 
I brought this into work and I think everyone had a slice. People said it was good, but no one really raved about it, or asked for the recipe, like they do when they love it. I personally thought it was too rich. I won’t make again. I would rather have just a lighter plain devil’s food cake.

text:
I didn't follow this recipe exactly. I had to make a few substitutions. Instead of sour cream, I used cream cheese. Instead of one large (6-8 serving) packet of chocolate pudding powder, I used 1 (4 serving) packet of Almond Joy pudding powder and 1 (4 serving)white chocolate pudding powder. The batter was very thick, but the cake came out great! It was very moist and delicious! I got lots of compliments! I served with strawberries and ice cream and no frosting. It was great!

text:
I make this exactly like the recipe, unless I use 2 9" round pans or make cupcakes, then I use frosting(I am going to try the Chocolate Glaze recipe from this website that some comments mention).I usually need to let it bake just a bit longer than the recipe says. 

I have also used this recipe and replaced it with white cake and vanilla pudding - also excellent. 

I get so many compliments from this recipe, I will probably never use a different recipe, not for chocolate or white cake anyway. My friends will say things like "Wow! That is the best chocolate cake I have ever had! You have to give me the recipe!" I just snicker because it is also so easy to make. I put a 9" layered cake in a cake box I bought at the store for a couple of dollars and my friends brother made a bet with her that I bought the cake from a bakery!

text:
Yummm. I made this as is except used mini chocolate chips, and it was perfectly delicious. I did end up baking it for about 58 minutes for a toothpick to come out clean in the center or the crack of the cake. But, it ended up having a nice crispy outside that was a good contrast to the beautifully moist inside.  I covered it with a chocolate ganache icing and sprinkled some more chocolate chips on top as well as powdered sugar.  Everyone loved it! Thanks for a great recipe.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
this is a moist, delicious cake which doesn't taste like it's from a mix. (I use Betty Crocker - no funny aftertaste), and substitute brewed coffee for the water. I also leave out the chocolate chips. I bake it in a large pan- about 17 x 13, until it's just done. Once out of the oven, I immediately take a skewer and poke holes into the top of the cake - all over it, then spread a thin coat of warm chocolate glaze (made with butter, cocoa and powdered sugar). keep spreading so it drips down into the cake, keeping it super moist. I wait a while, then add the remaining glaze/frosting. sometimes I top with roasted, chopped pecans or walnuts while the glaze is still warm.

text:
Thank you Denise for this awesome, easy recipe!  I made two bundt cakes using this recipe for my daughter's third birthday, cutting and shaping the cakes into the number three.  It turned out fabulous! I will say though, I used store bought icing to save time to top it, and I actually think the cake tastes much better without any icing at all (or probably with higher quality icing or just a dusting of powdered sugar).  I did make a couple slight changes, I only used 1/2 cup oil and 1/2 cup unsweetened applesauce, and I decreased the chocolate chips to around 1 to 1 1/4 cups of mini chips.  This will be my go to cake recipe from now on, and it helped my first attempt at baking my children's birthday cakes a huge success!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A friend asked me to make a "show-off" chocolate cake that he could give as a gift to the staff at his primary care physician's office... and this recipe filled the bill very nicely.  I used a high-quality, very dark chocolate, added 2 Tablespoons Chambord raspberry liquer to the batter, baked in 3 layers, and made a simple ganache (2 cups very dark chocolate melting chips, 1 cup heavy cream melted together and cooled on the counter to retain its lovely gloss) to frost. 

Split 2 layers horizontally, turned cut sides down and brushed lightly with a couple more Tablspoons Chambord, then assembled with a bit of ganache between layers, and frosted with the remaining ganache and garnished the top with chopped black walnuts.  The third layer I cut in half to make a "half cake" for my friend and his neighbors.
Both cakes were stored in fridge about 36 hours before serving...
His Dr. reminded him that he was "NOT supposed to be eating things like this, but it's REALLY good!"
No negative reviews, and he was very pleased with the results...
Great cake, lovely presentation, not for daily comsumption!

text:
Decadent - cut the morsels down to 1 cup and had to use 2-3oz small boxes of instant chocolate pudding (instead of the one large 5oz pkg called for) because it was all I had. Increased the water to 1 cup due to the density of batter with the increased instant pudding. Swapped coconut oil for the vegetable oil and used Egg Beaters instead of whole eggs for healthier option. This is a wonderfully dense, not-too-sweet chocolate cake that needs no frosting.

This recipe has many names. I first made in the 80's, was listed in our church's annual recipe book. It was called "Soul Food Chocolate Cake". Over the years I've tweaked. At the holidays, I put in crushed candy canes along with the chocolate chips and peppermint oil. Another variation is adding cranberries. There's enough sugar so that the cranberries are just sweet enough.

I made this cake for a family get together and topped it with the satiny chocolate glaze (as recommended by many reviewers), and I thought it turned out great. I give this recipe 4 stars because it is a delicious chocolate cake, but not everyone who tried it agreed.

text:
hubby requested chocolate cake for his birthday, so i began a short search and came across this one.  4000+ reviews and 5 star rating made this recipe the chocolate cake of choice.  i made some minor modifications, only because the devil's cake mix and instant pudding did not come in the sizes indicated in the ingredients.  i used a 16.5oz devil's food cake mix and 3.9oz instant pudding, with success.  this cake was extremely moist and absolutely delicious.  i admit i was a little skeptical, as i haven't purchased cake mix in a very long time (i prefer making foods from scratch).  i also made the satiny chocolate glaze to top off this cake and sprinkled with semisweet chocolate chips, as seen in the pic.  the satiny chocolate glaze recipe can be found on allrecipes as well.  this is a keeper, for sure!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was concerned...All of the cake mixes have been hit by the grocery shring ray, apparently. I purchased the pillsbury mix which was only 15.25oz...this was the largest package I could find. In addition, the pillsbury brand states that the mix contains pudding. I was worried the proportions and texture would be ruined. I made the cake precisecly according to direction and it was perfectly moist (not droopy wet) with a sweet (not sickeningly) and rich flavor. I only use the Hershey dark chocolate chips...they are worth the $2.69...you can actually taste the dark chocolate. In addition, I did not use an entire two cups of chocolate chips. I added approximately 3/4C chips to the mix, I then spread the mix into the bundt pan, upon which I sprinkled an additional 1/2C of the chips. I was alarmed at the gelatin like consistency of the mix; however, the cake did not seem to be affected. The cake was flavorful, dense but not clay-like, springy, and not overly sweet. You can feel satisfied with a small portion...and that way just cut the rest into small portions and freeze the rest. It should last a while this way.

Absolutely amazing! I make this cake often, and also take it with me as a hostess gift. It is always a hit! Depending upon the audience, I add anywhere between a quarter and a teaspoon and a half of cayenne pepper. The spice really makes the flavor even better. I always butter the pan well, use Daisy sour cream, and the best chocolate chips I can find, ghiradelli of course. I serve the cake dusted with powdered sugar with a scoop of ice cream. Best cake ever!

text:
I found this recipe years ago in the newspaper, it was called Triple Chocolate Cake, but I call it Bon Bon Cake because it is "good good"!
It makes me laugh that people will change the recipe and then rate it less than five stars, this recipe is perfect as is, yes it is overkill with the chocolate, but what a way to die!  If you want a "homemade" cake then go make a Wacky Cake, this is yummy and made at home in your kitchen so, to me it is "home made"!  While I have changed up the chips using peanut butter or butterscotch chips with yellow cake, the chocolate version remains my favorite. (if you use other chips be sure to dust them with flour as they will sink to the bottom for some reason)  And if you don't make a recipe as written and rate it low that means you are rating your own version of the recipe, not the original.

None
text:
It's so yummy! A tip for mixing in chocolate chips: before adding them to the batter, stir them with about a tablespoon of flour. This helps to keep them from sinking to the bottom of the pan while baking and keeps them suspended throughout the cake. I topped mine with a chocolate glaze and substituted an equal amount of coffee for the water to enhance the chocolate flavor. Lots of compliments on this one!

text:
I made this cake at this last minute on Christmas Day.  My favorite flavor is vanilla and this was not my go-to cake recipe but I figured others might prefer chocolate.  Cake turned out great, everyone loved it.  Dusted it with powered sugar.  I noticed that my devil's food cake was a 15 oz box and my chocolate pudding around 3.4 oz, so I just roughly scaled everything down - 3 eggs not 4, 2/3 cup oil and so on and it came out fine.  Substituted buttermilke and butter for the sour cream.  A very forgiving recipe!

text:
I made this cake for my best friends birthday and it was incredible!  It was very rich; just what a chocolate cake should be! I did not frost the cake and I was glad i chose not to because it really did not need anything extra. I did not use mini chips, as other reviewers suggested, and I had no problem with them sinking to bottom of the cake.  I also have used this basic recipe and changed cake/pudding/chip flavors with great success. My favorites were a carrot cake with white chocolate chips and butterscotch pudding.  I also made red velvet cake with vanilla pudding and white chocolate chips which was also devine!

text:
Stop right here!  My wife is a self proclaimed connoisseur of DARK chocolate.  I have spent years looking for something that didn't make her respond with the gratuitous "yeah, it's pretty good".  It doesn't matter how good the cake was, it was NEVER "chocolatey" enough.  This is THE FIRST CAKE that met her excited seal of approval as being.  To add to the glory, I'm not a dark chocolate fan but I really like this one.  I did cheat a bit by using half bittersweet chocolate which makes a huge difference, and used chocolate fudge pudding.  True that you don't "need" any icing, but I found the Easy Chocolate Bundt Cake Glaze on this site works great, and it's super easy.  If you are on a quest to find a cake so dark chocolatey good that it makes your head want to cave in, stop right here.

This cake was very moist and a little dense but not heavy. It has tons of chocolate flavor! I followed the recipe exactly (except I used mini chocolate chips as another reviewer suggested) and it came out perfect. I will be making this easy cake again. When greasing my bundt pan I used vegatable shortening and instead of flour I used cocoa powder. That way you don't get a white dusting on your chocolate cake.

text:
delish - i made these into cupcakes.  1. it made a LOT of cupcakes for me.  I got 30 from one recipe.  2. it took longer to bake than a normal cupcake recipe.  I started with my normal 18 minutes, but extended 2 minutes at a time until they were finally "toothpick clean" at 26 minutes.  I baked at 350 as the recipe indicated.  I also used 1/2 c. oil instead of 1 c. and added 1/3. c. milk.  Not sure if that helped or hurt, but just in case you need that info. they are slightly soft for a cupcake, but i think when i get a nice buttercream atop it'll hold together.  i'll also probably refrigerate the final product so it will be as firm as possible.

What a delicious cake! I used mini and regular size chocolate chips.  To keep them from sinking to the bottom of the cake, pour the chips in a bowl, then sprinkle them with a little of the dry cake batter; this coats them and keeps them from sinking. text:
As suggested I cut back on the oil and used the mini chocolate chips and the cake was amazing. To my misfortune our bundt pan had been thrown out a few weeks prior due to lack of use. I made this in two 9" pans then used an easy home made vanilla icing between the two to keep them together (milk, powdered sugar, and vanilla extract). I then drizzled the "Satiny Chocolate Glaze" (http://allrecipes.com/recipe/satiny-chocolate-glaze/detail.aspx) over the top along with the remaining icing. It ended up looking and tasting great! Side note: It was a great way to impress the girlfriend's parents.

text:
This case was moist and very chocolaty.  I used a 1/3 cup butter and 2/3 cups oil.  Otherwise made according to instructions.  Used rectangle pan and baked approximately 50 minutes.  This case was moist but I like a richer taste.  Maybe next time I will use all butter instead of oil, and milk or evaporated milk instead of water.  My son was not sold on the taste and he is usually my biggest fan.  Definitely for the mature chocolate lover.  May also use milk chocolate chips instead of semisweet chips.

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:
2
userID:
3117888
Display Name:
YummyT
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
45
favoritesCount:
456
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/757452.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this for book club ladies and what a hit.  I was begged for the recipe not only because it was so moist and chocolatey but the icing I added.  It is a coffee, cocoa & kahlua icing which gave it even more flavor.  Add 2 tblspns butter, softened, 1 1/2 cups powdered sugar to a bowl.  Heat 3 tblspns water and add to 1 tblspn granulated coffee, 1 tblspn cocoa.  Pour into bowl then add 2 tblspns kahlua and mix.  If too thin, add more powdered sugar, if too thick add dash water or kahlua.  I also added large Girhadelli chocolate chips.  This is a keeper for sure.  Next time I might try strawberry icing.  Thanks for a terrific recipe.

text:
I found a similar recipe years ago in a newspaper.  Mine also calls for 1/4 cup Kahlua, 1 tsp. cinnamon, and 2 Tablespoons grated orange peel (which I omit because we don't prefer it).  I also substitute mini chocolate chips for the regular ones because it adds that flavor without biting into a big chip.  

This cake also freezes well!

None
text:
I did change up the recipe a bit, based on other reviews. I substituted tofutti sour cream to make it non-dairy, and turned the warm water into coffee. I did use the full cup of oil. I baked it in mini cakes bundt pan for 20 minutes at 350, and then reduced the temperature for the rest of the time-until it was baked, was probably another 20-25 minutes. In the future I would probably change up the cake mix, pudding and eliminate the chocolate chips. This cake worked well in the bundt pans, but was not very chocolaty or even a 5 star cake. The cake was fast to make.  I would probably make it again with the changes I mentioned.

text:
I use allrecipes all the time, and this recipe is truly one of my favorites.  I changed nothing. I did however, use mini chocolate chips instead.  The key to success for me was exactly 55 minutes in a thoroughly preheated oven, and no less than 1-1/2 hrs. to cool.   You will think the cake is not done, but the chips have to harden again.  Amazing.  I can't keep it in my house.  It's gone so quick.

text:
this was so tasty! We made it for Christmas, since the girls wanted to make Jesus a Birthday cake... The cake mix I had was only 15.25 ounces and I had a cook n serve package of pudding (vs the "instant"). I had to add some flour to the batter until it seemed to be the right consistency (not sure how much I added, maybe 1/4 - 1/2 cup... plus had all ten fingers crossed!). Used dark and mint chocolate chips (the little green spots can look unappetizing if you are uninformed!) and Duncan Hines Amazing Glazes.. topped with a sprinkling of powdered sugar... Oh. My. Gosh. This was chocolate heaven!

text:
Grossly delicious!!! We drizzled ours with hershey caramel syrup, the cake soaked up the syrup but the taste was phenomenal. Loved the easy ingredients however all those things mixed together makes the batter very thick. The thickness caused my cheap wm blender to burn out. I had to bake mine about 15-20 extra minutes longer than the recipe called for because the fork didnt want to come out clean, might have over baked it just a lil but I wanted it to hold together well so I am very happy with the results. Hubby and kids love it too however beware the effects it has on three year olds lol.

text:
This is an awesome cake that I have been making for years but this recipe is almost identical to the "Cake Doctor" cookbook.  The only thing different is that this recipe uses 1/2 cup more oil which you can leave out (the recipe is for 1/2 C water and 1/2 C oil)  and the cake is still fantastic and the best choc. cake I have ever made.

text:
I made this in a cupcake version which obviously needed tweaking. Instead of a 5.9 oz pkg of pudding, I used 2 of the small ones (1.2 oz I think), fat free sour cream, and 1 cup of mini semisweet choc chips and 1 cup of large milk choc chocolate chips (plus the other ingredients). I baked for 16 minutes on 325 and they were incredible!! I also iced them with my favorite icing (Triple Chocolate Fudge Chip) - yumm!

Not that this recipe needs one more review, but I made this for my son's birthday party and it came out awesome!  I used Duncan Hines cake mix.  I didn't have sour cream on hand, so I substituted yogurt.  I also left out the chocolate chips because it didn't want it to be overly chocolatey since I was going to frost the whole thing with chocolate fudge frosting.  It came out dense and moist and just perfect!   On a side note, I also tried some recipes from pretty blogs with disastrous results, which is why I will always come back to this site, the reviews are so very helpful!

text:
This cake is amazing. Great texture. If using this for cupcakes, bear in mind the amount of oil stains the liners, doubling up before baking doesn't really help. (Thought it would.) You might want to wait for them to dry and add a second afterwards if using for a pop of color. Overall, great recipe, will use again. Thank you!

text:
OMG!!! I didn't actually try the chocolate version of this recipe but I am sure it is just divine!! I wanted to spice up the cake box recipe & found this but only had vanilla cake on hand. So instead of the Devil's Food Cake, I used Vanilla & instead of the chocolate pudding mix, I used vanilla. I also used about a cup of chocolate chunks. It was soooo gooood!!! & I can't wait to try the chocolate version! I also recommend not used the whole package of the pudding mix because I have used that amount before & it made the cake way to moist, as if it wasn't done all the way. I used about half of that & it turned out perfect.

I started this recipe by "breaking the rules".  I used a small box of pudding and did 1/2 c oil and 1/2 c applesauce.  THEN, I preheated the oven, got interrupted, turned it off, put the cake in the oven, and noticed 45 min into baking that the oven was off.

STILL, i turned the oven on, baked it for a while longer and it came out amazingly.  I can't imagine this turning out any better.

SOOOO good.  I used the mini chips instead of big ones.  Made it the night before I needed it.  SO moist and yummy.  Just a big bunch of tasty fun.  Kids and adults, they ALL loved it!

This cake is perfectly named.  It is rich, moist, delicious and you need a full gallon of milk at the ready!  I followed the recipe exactly and it turned out wonderfully.  The regular sized chocolate chips melted into fantastic pockets of ooey goodness. A friends' daughter commented "How did she get the frosting on the inside of the cake?"  Love this recipe, and so did my party guests!

This is five stars in my book not only because of taste but because of how easy they are to make. Delicious.

Display Name:
Rita

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My mother made this identical cake back in the late 70's, early 80's. It was called 'chocolate cake for chocolate freaks'. She passed away in 1982, but this is such a fantastic recipe that I have continued making it all these years and haven't changed a thing. Only thing is -really play up the chocolate and frost it with fudge frosting. (homemade of course, not canned). 1 box confectioners sugar, 1tsp good vanilla extract, 1 stick butter (real please and room temperature) pinch of salt and 1/2 cup regular cocoa. Lightly whisk in bowl, add cold milk, start with about 4 tablespoons - add till all incorporated together- but not thin. Mix on high speed 1-2 minutes. It should be light, fluffy, creamy - and delicious.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
My inner baker and my inner man were at conflict with other over how to bake this cake...by the way, this was my very first cake I have ever baked.

My inner baker wanted to follow the recipe exactly...my inner man wanted to mess with it a bit.  They both won!

I used all the ingredients as listed...inner baker wins!

BUT...I added one ingredient and cooked it a bit different...inner man wins out there!

First off, I did not bake it in a bundt pan but rather 2 round cake pans.  After letting them cool I added my extra ingredient: chocolate fudge frosting.

I spread a generous layer of the frosting on one of the cake rounds and put the other round on top of that.

Then I melted extra chocolate chips and drizzled over the top of the cake letting it run down the sides of the cake.  Once all the melted chips were on the cake, I spread the melted chips evenly across the top and as it cooled it hardened a bit.

People were amazed that this was the first cake I have ever made and asked me how I could ever make a better one.  Ahhh, but I have another thought, today I will take the extra frosting and frost the sides too and use the extra chips for the top of the cake.

text:
I wouldn't call this "Too Much Chocolate Cake"!  It's excellent and just right.  One reviewer mentioned using mini chocolate chips to keep them from sinking, and you can do that.  However, if you have regular sized chocolate chips you can coat them in a light dusting of flour and it should keep them from sinking.  I did this the first time I made this cake and it worked fine.  I am making this again today and I'm trying the mini chips.  Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
Bravo! Best chocolate cake I've ever had. My mom, who doesn't like any kind of cake, took one taste of this cake and she loved it. It's very moist and super rich, so have a glass of milk on-hand! Best part about this recipe is that it's easy to make! I've spent much longer making desserts that aren't as good as this one. I used dark chocolate morsels instead of semi-sweet, and it was yummy. Also, the recipe itself doesn't call for a glaze even though there's a glaze in the photo, so I made a simple chocolate glaze to pour on top. If you've gone this far with the chocolate, might as well go all the way! This recipe is definitely going in my recipe box, and you bet I'll be making it for years to come.

text:
Thought this cake was great and easy to make. Not life-changing, as the hype may have you believe, but very good.  Next time, I will take other reviewers' suggestions and use mini chocolate chips, or full sized white chocolate chips.  I used a little less than the full cup of oil, but kept everything else the same.  I baked in a bundt pan and found that at 50 minutes, my toothpick came out completely covered with batter.  Baked another 20 minutes, which made the toothpick come out more cleanly, but not totally clean.  The cake was baked through and did not fall.  I actually think I should have baked the cake for another 15 minutes instead of 20, for a total baking time of 65 minutes.  Next time I will try that, and also reduce the temperature for the last 20 minutes to 325, as other reviewers have suggested.  Very easy cake to make.  Came out of the pan just fine.  Used Satiny Chocolate Glaze, also from this website, on top.

text:
I have a recipe very similar to this that I got out of a cake doctor book, the only difference is the amount of oil. It is a very good recipe. One way to not have all the chocolate chips sink to the bottom is save some of the dry cake mix and mix it with the chocolate chips, then after you have mixed all the other ingredients put the chocolate chips in and mix just until mixed. I have used that method and have never had chocolate chips at the bottom of the pan.

text:
i made this cake for my dads 47th bday and all my family ate this yumi cake up.i did a little twist to the cake after it was done   first i froze the cake for about 30mins. than i melted 2 cups of chocolate chips with a tad of oil and used that for the frosting. than i put the cake in the freezer for another 30 mins. melted 2 more cups of chocolate chips with oil and did a second coat. after that i mixed 3.4 oz of cheese cake pudding and put it in the center of the cake. i put in the freezer again till the chocolate coat was hard. it was so delicious. thanks Denise for this recipe

TRISKELE

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5840433.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If I could give this recipe 10 stars, I would.  It's a simply awesome chocolate cake.  It needs absolutely nothing on top.  It's incredibly rich, moist, and flavorful all on its own.  I didn't have sour cream, but did have a large container of low-fat plain yogurt, so I used that.  Also used 1/2 cup of brewed coffee instead of water.  It turned out beautifully.  Mix the chocolate chips with a little bit of the dry cake mix before stirring them in...they won't sink to the bottom of the pan.  Thanks for a great recipe! Update: I've made this probably 25 times now and it still gets gobbled up faster than I can believe.  I now use a bag of mini chocolate chips instead of the regular size ones and somehow it tastes even more chocolatey.  :)  Subbing coffee for the water is a must for even more of a chocolate flavor boost!

None
text:
I made this to cover with fondant for a mothers day cake. I used the recipe exactly with big chocolate chips...I quite liked the cruch they gave, but may use mini chips for a smoother texture next time. I used 2 x 9 inch pans and baked for 48 mins. Stuffed the middle with whipped ganache and covered with a ganache glaze then fondant. It held the icing wonderfully, tasted amazing, kept fresh and squishy for 2 days before serving and was devored in rapt silence! It is very rich, so it is nice to serve with vanilla ice-cream and in small portions. This will be my 'go to' chocolate cake recipe.

text:
This is an amazing chocolate cake! I am one of those people who usually look down on making box cake recipes but it turned out fabulous! I made it for a friend's birthday and there was none left! I followed the suggestions to use 1/2 cup of oil, 1/3 cup of milk, 1 cup of mini chocolate chips, 1 tsp of vanilla extract, and 1/2 cup of warm coffee instead of water. I also topped it off with the satiny chocolate glaze(the ghirardelli semi-sweet chocolate chips work really well for this) and toasted walnuts, and put raspberries and blueberries in the center. The fruit was a delicious supplement to the chocolate! SO GOOD!

text:
I made this yesterday for a family party.  I doubled the recipe as written (use a big bowl!) and used the mini chips.  I cooked it in a sheet cake pan (12x16) and it came out great!  I can't remember the exact time it took-I'd say about 45 minutes but it was until the top was no longer liquid and firmish when pressed.  I frosted it in pan with buttercream frosting.  It was a hit!!  Descriptions like rich and chocolatey were used.  Needless to say folks took some home with them, too-a good comment for my family of great cooks! Will definitely make this again and am looking forward to trying the recipe in a bundt pan.  Thanks for this great recipe!  *****I want to add that I've made this a number of times as written as a cake with great results.  However, this week I've made it 3 times as cupcakes for various events.  I find that the oil is too much for cupcakes and leave the bottoms a bit greasy (though they taste fine).  For cupcakes I'd recommend using 1/2 cup of oil and the foil/paper combo as cupcake liners. The recipe makes 2 dozen cupcakes. I sold 2 dozen very quickly at a fundraiser yesterday with a number of kids comng back for seconds!  I used the minichips and buttercream frosting-yummy!

This cake wasn't quite what I expected. It came out with more of a brownie texture than a cake texture. I pretty much followed the recipe exactly, except I used light sour cream and mini chocolate chips. It actually took 1 hour and 45 minutes to bake! I'm really not sure why, but I'm still astonished by that. I topped it with Satiny Chocolate Glaze from this site and served it as one of the deserts at a party I was hosting. Some people loved the cake, others thought it was just ok, which is why I rated it 3 stars. I may or may not make this again, however, I'd be interested to see what a vanilla version of this cake tastes like.

text:
I do not consider myself to be a cake lover, and usually only eat it to be polite at birthday parties,  but I do love this cake.  In fact, my 11-yr-old son requested chocolate cake for his birthday, and, cringing at the thought of another store-bought mix with store-bought frosting, I came to allrecipes.com.  I'm so glad I did!  My only issue with this recipe is with its name:  I contend that there is no such thing as "too much chocolate."  That said, this certainly is a cake for those who really love chocolate!  Very moist, dense and flavorful, there can surely not be a better chocolate cake recipe anywhere, and as for me, I have stopped looking.  This was very easy to make.  I used the Satiny Chocolate Glaze with this, and it was wonderful, but this cake doesn't really need icing.  Try this - you won't be disappointed.

text:
Let me just say that this is a wonderful chocolate cake recipe.  I made this and brought it to work for someone's birthday and got mostly rave reviews.  Some said it tasted like the cake you buy in a restaurant!  Only one person didn't care for it, saying it was 'too chocolatey.'  LOL!  I took someone's idea of using unsweetened cocoa powder to powder the bundt pan, instead of flour, and I didn't like that.  I could taste the cocoa powder in some bites.  Left a bitter taste in my mouth.  Next time I will use pam spray and flour.  I used the Satiny Chocolate Glaze recipe to frost it and then also used unsweetened applesauce in place of oil.  Will be making again this weekend for a dinner party!  Just love this heated up in the microwave for 20 seconds!

text:
A little taste of this cake can take care of a chocolate fix really quick.  My son and I made this cake for his birthday.  He was more than pleased with the outcome.  We made this cake and used the Rich Chocolate Frosting recipe to top it off.  So wonderful!  Everyone loved it! However, I did have to change the recipe and "lighten" it up a bit.  I did what another reviewer suggested by exchanging veg oil for applesauce, sour cream for fat free, egg whites, and used fat free - sugar free pudding mix.  It tasted so sinful ... just a little healthier than the original.

This cake is perfect!  I've made it a dozen times at least, I follow the recipe exactly as stated (except I put chocolate icing on it as well), and everyone always asks for the recipe.  In my oven, it needs exactly one hour to cook, and I would highly recommend greasing AND flouring the pan (or else the chocolate chips can burn making it difficult to remove).  It's not gooey at all, just moist and delicious.

text:
This is a great, dense cake which makes it perfect for decorating...especially for a wedding!  The first time I tried this I felt it tasted a little on the oily side, so I substituted 1/2c of melted butter for 1/2c of oil and that is a nicer flavor for me.  I also always add real vanilla to a box cake mix, because this cancels out the artificial vanilla that is used in mixes. You get less of a "cake mix" taste, and more of a homemade flair! I also used the mini chips like suggested by others.  Great to have this in your back pocket!!!

Great cake. I used regular sized peanut butter chips in chocolate-flavored batter and pudding mix.. yummy!! The chips did NOT sink to the bottom as another reviewer experienced.. the cake batter is so thick that it suspends them in place. I overcooked this slightly - don't do it! This cake is amazing!  I haven't needed to change anything in the recipe; and it is now my "go to" dessert when asked to bring something to a get together.  I tried using the mini chips like some suggested, and they still fell to the bottom. Also, I accidentally bought sugar free instant pudding, and it didn't change the taste at all, so I will continue to cut some of the sugar by using the sugar free pudding.

text:
This was great!  I wasn't wanting to make it at first, because I wanted to make a homemade cake--not the box stuff.  But this didn't taste anything like the boxes, and was probably one of the best chocolate cakes I've made.  Very very moist, and great with the chocolate chips too, though you could probably leave them out if you didn't have any and it would still taste fine.  I made mine in two 8 or 9 inch cake pans, and frosted with a nice thick chocolate frosting.  Not only did it turn out great, but it was quick and easy too!!!

The first time I made this, I made cupcakes. I didn't have time to get them to friends the day I baked them, but even two days later they were still moist and delicious. Everyone said they were the best cupcakes they'd ever eaten! I used mini chocolate chips in that batch. The second time I baked them, I tried melting the chips and adding them...needless to say, TERRIBLE idea! I completely forgot that there was pudding mix in the batter and of course, they gelled up and made the cupcakes very dry and hard. I guess it's good to learn from your mistakes!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cake is awesome!! I followed the recipe without making any changes. Well, the only thing I did was to toss the chocolate chips in a little bit of flour before adding them to the batter. This prevents the chips from sinking to the bottom, like some people have noted. I used the Satiny Chocolate Glaze recipe from this site to pour over the cake and then dusted the top with powdered sugar. For the glaze, if you don't have corn syrup, I just used 1 tbsp white sugar and 1/4 tbsp water instead. It turned out just fine! My husband said it looked store-bought and my brother-in-law asked to take some home for later. Since my oven is so old and unreliable, I did have to bake it for about 15 minutes longer than stated. Excellent recipe and I'll definitely make this again!

text:
This is an amazing cake - I made it for our son's birthday and everyone loved it - hardly a piece left for him to take home.  I used strong coffee in place of the water and 1/2 cup of oil, baked it in a 9x13 panfor approx. 40-45 mins. at 350 degrees. I'm going to try some of the other combinations suggested, but for chocolate lovers this is a keeper.  I used bittersweet chips that I tossed with a teaspoon of flour before mixing into the batter - the chips don't sink to the bottom, this is a tip I got years ago and it works every time.

text:
I have made this a few times in the last month and get rave reviews every time. To make it a little "lighter" I use sugar free pudding, replace 1/2 cup oil with 1/2 cup unsweetened applesauce, and use low fat sour cream or plain yogurt. Topped with the Satiny Chocolate Glaze recipe from this site and you have a dense, rich awesome treat! The favorite flavor combinations have been Devils food cake/chocolate pudding/peanut butter chips followed by Chocolate cake (+2 tsp peppermint extract)/chocolate pudding/mint chocolate chips.

text:
You would think this was my first time baking - I completely forgot the oil, I made an absolute mess of my hand mixer since the batter was so thick (due to the lack of oil), I accidentally turned ON the hand mixer while trying to scrape the overly thick batter off the beaters -flinging cake batter everywhere!  I burnt both hands... I'm surprised I didn't burn my house down too -it obviously wasn't a baking day -maybe I can blame it all on me being 39 weeks prego!  At the end of it all, the cake was still surprisingly moist!  I used fat-free sour cream and sugar-free pudding and covered the cake in Satiny Chocolate Glaze.  Next time I'll use 1c of mini chocolate chips instead of the 2c regular (since they did sink) and, of course, the oil called for in the recipe.

Wonderful idea of adding Chocolate pudding into cake.Imagine ,I didnt use cake mix ,sour cream.Prepared it from scratch like regular chocolate cake but replaced half of oil with 200 gms of chocolate pudding.and even cut down on sugar as well  . I have never eaten a better cake in my life which had this level of moisture ,sweetness and this less calories almost minimum 90 calories less than a regular cake per serving by replacing oil with pudding and better taste on the top of it. Thanks a lot for it.

text:
So... I made this cake twice in a week and it was gobbled up by my boyfriend and their friends. It's TOO GOOD! Very moist but not heavy. Not overly sweet either, which surprised me because of the chocolate chips on top of the cake mix. For a glaze I made a simple ganache: 1/2 cup heavy cream, 3/4 cup bittersweet chocolate. Bring the cream to a boil then immediately pour over chopped chocolate and stir until completely incorporated and shiny. This one is definitely going into the recipe book!

text:
I hate to be the odd one out, but this did not work for me.  I was super excited to try this because I'm a big fan of box cake mixes and assumed since this started w/that as its base, it would be like a box cake, only BETTER.  Um, not so much.  I tried one fresh out of the oven (un-frosted) and was underwhelmed...so, I thought I'd reserve judgement until they were frosted...still underwhelmed, so I thought I'd see the guests (made them for a baby shower) reactions....still underwhelmed (they thought they were brownies!), so I tried them after a couple of drinks, STILL underwhelmed (and if a chocolate cupcake doesn't taste great after a few drinks when you're starving, it never will)...  I followed the recipe to a *T* (other than baking in cupcakes, rather than a bundt pan)...my batter was very thick and my cupcakes had very little taste, less than a traditional box mix chocolate cake.  I won't be making again, but hundreds of other people can't be wrong, so def try it for yourself!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I cut the oil down to 1/2c and I added extra warm water to get a good consistency. The recipe made 12 cupcakes & 1 round cake pan (w/ bundt piece inserted)... I baked the cupcakes for 16 minutes & they were perfect! Just make sure you do not fill past the 1/2 way mark because this recipe nearly doubles in size once baked. I made the cupcakes in oversized Nut & Party cups (from Wilton) & we ate them warm- it tasted like a molton lava cake w/ the melted chocolate chips! Yummy!! And unlike most cakes, this gets better the day after. It was so moist & it reminded me of a chocolate muffin from Costco! Mmmm this is my new go-to recipe for chocolate cake.

YUM!!!!! I made this cake for my father-in-law's birthday and it as absolutely decadent. I would use mini chocolate chips next time, because they sank, but otherwise no change. Be aware that the batter will look VERY different than a typical cake mix - waxy, whipped, solid - but resist the temptation to doctor it! Comes out perfect, moist, just the right amount of density - YUM! I topped it with the "whipped cream cream cheese frosting" from this site. A+!
