text:
It is 2 hours before my baby's Dr. appointment, and I am extremely disappointed with the results.  I decided to bake something nice for the Dr. and staff for the holidays, and thought this would be a no brainer with its rave reviews.  I made two 8 inch square cakes, and I ended up eating a quarter of the one pan trying to debate if I should bother taking it to the Dr or not.  It IS denser than the cake box mix, but that's all the difference I taste.  Maybe I'll just make the Satiny chocolate glaze and give it in so I don't waste it, but what a disappointment!  UPDATE:  I originally gave this a 1 star, but had to change it to 4.  With the left over, my toddler couldn't get enough of it (he doesn't really like too much sweets believe it or not...maybe the "bittersweet" chocolate chips made it more palatable for him).  My 6 year old nephew cried "THIS IS THE BEST BEST CHOCOLATE CAKE EVER! THIS IS BETTER THAN MY MOM'S!!"  Even my sister exclaimed what a great, rich cake this was.  Hmm, perhaps it's just a personal taste preference (thus the 4 star) but I'm glad I ended up giving the other cake to the Doctor and staff.

text:
Oh my goodness... if you love chocolate this recipe is most definitely for you. It was incredibly moist and rich. It is probably the simplest chocolate cake you can make with such phenomenol results. I ended up using chocolate fudge cake mix and the chocolate fudge pudding, but thats simply because I'm not a huge fan of devil's food cake. It turned out better than I might have thought. I put a simple chocolate glaze on it because I wasn't sure if it would need a topping and after trying it I now know that it most certainly could have been just as good without the glaze. The one questionable thing that I ran into making this cake is the pudding package. I could only find packages that were 3.9 ounces and the recipes states that it needs a 5.9 ounce package. To resolve that I simple bought two and used one and then approximately one half of the other one. Since the cake was amazing I imagine that that worked out well.

text:
I made this recipe into chocolate cupcakes and at first I was concerned at the consistency of the batter. However, I did use other reviewers suggestions and used 1/2 c. oil, 1/3 c. milk, and 1 c. mini semi-sweet chocolate chips. The first batch that I made I took them out of the oven too soon (after 15-17 mins) and the tops collapsed. So the second batch I left in for 19-22 mins and they turned out perfect. However, take my advice and do not eat them until the next day....they are amazing!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this cake for years, with a slight twist - mix small pkg. instant choc. pudding with 3/4 c milk; blend in devil's food cake mix and 2 eggs; stir in 12 oz choc. chips - bake 45-50 min in greased bundt. Seems healthier as there's no sour cream or oil and it gets RAVES when I take it to new moms, etc. Honestly, every time I make it (twice a month?) I am asked for the recipe, and am embarassed for folks to see how easy it is : ) We call it Triple Chocolate Cake - I buy choc chips in bulk at Sam's and stay stocked up on cake and pudding mix so I can knock this out in a jiffy.

text:
I JUST made this cake today along with a glaze from this site.  I can't have sugar but the birthday boy and guests absolutely loved it.  I did a couple things different.  I did only use 3/4 C oil and with the regular chips I used only 1 1/2 C.  I also made it in two 9" cake pans instead of the bundt pan. I put some glaze on the first layer and then made a layer of cut raspberries on that.  I then put the second layer of cake on the top of that, frosted the top of the cake with the glaze and let the remainder of glaze ooze down the sides.  When completely done, I took 6 raspberries and put them in two little areas of three each for decoration.

This is my favorite cake ever!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
I used the basic recipe but changed it up a little. My changes produced an Instant Mocha Fudge Layer cake. Here's what I did. First of all I used 2-8" round cake pans instead of the bundt. I greased them and used cocoa to dust them with. To the warm water I added 1 well rounded tablespoon of instant coffee granules. I also added 2 teaspoons of real almond extract. I took the advice of others and used the mini morsels. That way there weren't large chunks of chocolate in the cake. Since I didn't have enough confectioners sugar to make my own frosting, I used some Dunkin Hines whipped chocolate frosting that I already had. I mixed 2 teaspoons of instant coffee granules in a little bit of warm milk and mixed it in the frosting.  This cake was very moist and each layer baked up nicely. My family loved it and I'll definitely be making it again. Thanks for the recipe!!

I changed things just a bit: Pillsbury DARK chocolate cake mix (with pudding in the mix), SMALL box of chocolate FUDGE pudding, 1 cup VANILLA YOGURT, 1/2 cup of STRONG COFFEE, and the MINI-CHOCOLATE CHIPS someone suggested.

I am going to try this recipe with a lemon cake mix and lemon pudding, lemon yogurt, and lemonaide for the liquid.
I'll also try subbing toffee bits for the chocolate chips.

Can't wait!

UPDATE 9-20011: I have since made this cake a million times in a million different versions and have ALWAYS gotten rave reviews. The most recent was using this as a small sheet cake at my parents' 40th wedding anniversary celebration. It worked fantastic - moist and very tasty cake. I did one chocolate, one white, and one marble. I used white chocolate pudding, white cake mix, and milk for the white one and no chocolate chips.

country:
None
text:
I made this as a sheet cake in a 13 x 9 (?) pan and baked it for 35 minutes at 350. I also first beat the eggs using my Kitchen Aide mixer, added the sour cream, oil, and water and mixed these ingredients thoroughly before adding the box of pudding and cake mix. When I added the dry mixes, I only mixed until thoroughly blended, then added the chocolate chips. I sprayed my cake pan well with Pam, then poured cake batter into pan and baked in lower third of the oven for 35 minutes. I checked with a toothpick as well as testing for doneness by touching the top of the cake and watched for it to bounce back. When cooled for about an hour, I topped with the satiny chocolate glaze to complete this wonderful cake. 
Soooo easy and seemingly foolproof. Everyone loves this cake!

text:
I'm not a huge chocolate lover, but this is an awesome recipe.  I'm not even really sure how anyone's cake couldn't come out, even with varying the recipe a bit.  I used a cake mix that was only 15oz, compared to the 18.25oz called for.  I used sugar free pudding mix and didn't use the full 5.9oz that was called for.  I used a bit less than 1C of sour cream and my cake STILL came out perfect!

I also used the satiny chocolate glaze recipe found on this site, paired w/fresh strawberries.  I did use larger choco-chips, but chopped them in my chopper to spread the chocolatey-goodness.

This is my new go-to dessert, and I'll be trying this recipe w/ different mixes and pudding combos.  Next up:  strawberry cake, banana cream pudding and white chocolate chips.

text:
This is the perfect chocolate cake just as directed, with these warm, bursting pockets of semi melted chocolate (the chips) that surprise you in each bite.  Try this for a special occasion (we did for my sister's birthday), and you will not be disappointed.  It's even better the next day warmed for a few secs in the microwave.  Note - do not go for this cake if you're obsessed with finding a fudgey chocolate cake (I know I do that sometimes!)...this is chocolatey, not fudgey.  Enjoy!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow- what a cake! Easy to prep too! I baked in the evening (using mini chocolate chips, which worked wonders), allowed the cake to cool overnight in the bundt pan, and lightly placed a piece of plastic wrap over the top. I believe this helps to lock in the moisture better. The cake came out perfectly in the morning. I also used the Satiny Chocolate Glaze recipe from this site to drizzle over the top (yum). The inside was nice and moist and the edges were a little crispy (as recipe says). I think next time I will bake for less time, as the moist texture is one to be enjoyed. Overall, a very tasty (and chocolaty) cake!

This is my secret cake weapon. No one will know what hit them until they taste it... something like that. It is VERY moist and dense. I love the flavor, and I'm not a chocolate cake person. I agree with a few other reviewers here saying that using mini chocolate chips works better. I have tried the regular size chips, and if thats all you have in your pantry, than it will work. You might find that its a little too melty and it falls apart easily. Everyone will love this cake!

People fight over this at my place of work. Make sure that you test the cake with a knife before bringing it out. It wont really come out completely clean...that the nature of this doctor'ed cake recipe. I find that this recipe takes a little longer in the oven (well in my crappy oven anyway) Just wait til your knife comes out mostly clean and youll be happy.

Wow!  I made this for my chocolate-loving father-in-law for his birthday and he loved it!  It is so rich and so chocolatey.  Next time I think I will use a silicone bundt pan, because it took forever to cool down enough to invert. Thye completely melted and made the cake just super rich and moist.  It was a total hit at our holiday potluck!

This cake does not taste at all like a mix is used. It is so easy to make, too. My 13 year-old granddaughter baked it at our house when spending the night. Her mother had been baking a cake that was supposedly the "best" chocolate cake. However, everyone agrees this one "takes the cake!" I have made this several times. The only thing I have changed is I use mini chocolate chips. They don't sink to the bottom as the larger ones sometimes do. We also prefer a chocolate icing on it, but when in a hurry the confectioner's sugar is good. Great recipe--thanks!

A keeper for sure!  A couple of substitutions made it more healthy and the taste was still wonderful.  We used lowfat yogurt instead of sour cream and used 3/4 cup applesauce + 1/4 cup oil instead of 1 cup oil.  I also used a package of peanut butter chips instead of chocolate chips. The Satiny Chocolate Glaze from this site (thanks for the suggestions, everybody!) made this cake over the top.

text:
My first attempt of this cake a year or so ago was a failure, I didnt cook it long enough I guess but it was eaten and enjoyed. I decided to try it again for a pregnant friend of mine who is coming for dinner. After buying all the ingredients I come home to see I dont have oil..so I use the little bit I have left, about 1/4C..added 1/4C applesauce, then topped it off with a 1/2C of 1% milk. Also use low-fat sour cream. I used 1C of chopped chocolate chips, and save the other cup for the glaze. I cooked mine at 325 for 75 minutes, it wasn't jiggly when I took it out..I didnt want another collapse haha seriously teh most moist cake i've ever eaten, everyone commented on that and how delicious it was, pieces were taken home! Will stick to cooking it this way from now on!

text:
I made this cake for Valentine's Day. I prepared it in two heart-shaped cake pans. Although the edges were a little crusty by the time the center became done, it was fine after I frosted it with a chocolate buttercream frosting. (I will try it next time with less oil) Very moist on the inside with a very rich chocolate taste. I used mini-chocolate chips, and thought the texture was great. My husband and another couple loved it. Served it with a few raspberries on the side. Denise, thanks for sharing your recipe!

text:
I made a simple chocolate ganache icing for this cake.  Just bring 1 cup of heavy cream to a boil (don't let it boil too much or it will spill over) and pour over 1 package of semi-sweet dark chocolate chips, whisk (or use stand mixer) until creamy and pour over cooled cake.  Delicious!!!

text:
I would not change anything about the cake recipe.  It was awesome!   I did top it with the Chocolate Ganache recipe from  INGRIDEVOGEL  as suggested after watching the cake video.  I made a half batch of the ganache & it went  with the cake well.  My friends at work loved it.  The cake baked for 55 minutes and it was perfect.  I let it cool one and a half hours in the pan, as directed.  Thank you for sharing the recipe.
8-2-2018 Follow Up:  
By now,  I  have also made this recipe as standard aka regular-sized cupcakes.  I used the paper liners that come with the outer foil liner (both layers attached (JoAnn)  and both layers loose (Walmart or Meijer).  Both kinds of liners worked great in cupcake pans.  I used my Pampered Chef scoops.  It took 1 scoop of small plus  1 scoop of medium for each cupcake with 17 minutes baking time at 350 degrees.  The toothpick testing does not really work because of the chocolate chips.   The result was 34 cupcakes.  

 I also made trays of mini cupcakes (1.25 inches diameter on bottom) using paper liners in cupcake pans.  I put the 1 scoop of batter in each liner using the small Pampered Chef scoop.  This was at   350 degrees with 9 minutes baking time.  It all went well.  I put chocolate ganache on the cupcakes.

text:
This recipe is definitely chocolaty!!  I made it for my boyfriend for his birthday. He and the family loved it, and went back for seconds.

I followed the recipe as written. Although they don't make 18.25 oz cake mix anymore. So I added 3 oz of cake mix from another box.  I also used 1.5 cups of mini-chips (so they would melt completely)  instead of 2 cups of regular chips.  I topped the cake with a chocolate ganache garnished with fresh raspberries.   Note: Cook time for my oven was 60 - 70 mins.

I will definitely use this recipe again but in this chocolate lover's opinion you only really need to add 1 cup of mini chocolate chips. 

Variations to try: 
Make it with reduced fat ingredients and substitute apple sauce for the oil. 

Top with a raspberry glaze garnished with fresh raspberries

Bon Appétit!!

Display Name:
Aaron A

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6362904.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was very nervous about this cake when I was shopping for ingredients. Simply put, I couldn't find any boxes the size this recipe says. All cake boxes were 15.75 oz instead of 18.75 and as for puddings, none would add up to 5.9. I ended up getting 3x 2.1oz boxes which made me think this recipe would be doomed... too much pudding powder and not enough cake. Even when mixing it all up, my batter didn't "pour" into my pan, it was more a dough and flopped. I had to break it up into chunks and press into my bundt pan. Baked as it says and let it cool for nearly two hours. I was surprised how much it has risen and although having a little trouble getting it out the pan, it held its shape. In fact, it was looking like a normal cake. I drizzled some hot chocolate syrup on the top figuring it had enough chocolate as it was. What I cut into was a very dense, moist chocolate cake. The chocolate chips were spread evenly throughout much to my delight. Flavorwise, its as the name says. I only give four stars because although good, I would have prefered a lighter version rather than so dense, probably a result of the sizing issues. Not sure where people are shopping that Jell-O and Duncan Hines makes their stuff in these sizes but it isn't around me.

text:
I made this based on the ratings and IT WAS AWESOME! I didnt change a thing from the original recipe and it turned out GREAT! One thing I learned from another reviewer was to not mistake the chocolate chips in the batter for uncooked batter when you are testing it for doneness. I overcooked mine a bit due to thinking that the chocolate chips were uncooked batter. It was an amazing cake and I can't wait to make it again!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Super easy recipe. This is truly an incedibly delicious cake full of deep full chocolate flavor. In order to make it perfect be sure to use top quality semi-sweet chocolate chips (ex: Ghirardelli or equivalent), use good quality Italian extra virgin olive oil, and mix the cake mix and pudding mix together with hot (not warm) tap water before adding the rest of the ingredients. This helps the chocolate bloom and deepen in flavor. When completely cooled I make a Chocolate ganache with heavy whipping cream and semi-sweet chocolate chips and pour it on top of the cake. It is amazing!!

text:
Chocolate heaven!!! Everyone who has tasted this cake loves it. My only substitutions are 1cup applesauce for the oil (keeps it moister), and I like the mini chocolate chips as they "float" throughout the cake.  I have experimented with this recipe and you can use different flavors of cake mix and coincide flavors of pudding, using white chips as a sub (i.e.:butter pecan/butterscotch pudding & chips). It has turned out great each time.

text:
I've been making this recipe for years (got it from a friend long ago) so was thrilled to see it here. It's so simple but an absolute winner.  My recipe also calls  for icing sugar to be dusted on top when cool, which is a terrific (and light) finish, but lately I've been doing something different to great acclaim. I add peppermint to the cake batter and then frost with a green mint butter cream icing. As an added bonus, I crush up chocolate mint cookies (or mint chocolate bar) and sprinkle on the icing. My friends go nuts!!! If you like chocolate and mint, I highly recommend that option.

Great cake for the chocolate lover which I am. I Set aside a little of the instant pudding powder in a zip lock bag & add the chocolate chips to it & shake up. After cake ingredients are mixed I add and stir in. This keeps the chips from all sinking to the bottom. A delicious & easy cake to make.

text:
I gave 4 stars because it needs a bit of modification to be perfect but if you follow chef joy's suggestions of only 1/2 cup of oil and 1 cup of chocolate chips this cake comes out perfect. I always bake mine in two  9 inch rounds put caramel and  pecans on it for a turtle cake. Super yummy. I wanted to add that boxed cake mixes have less in them they are only 16.25 ounces now I think.  I still use the same amounts,  and it comes out great.  You can also use vanilla cake mix, and vanilla pudding for a great vanilla cake. I have left out the chocolate chips completely and prefer this without them less sweet. I make cakes from scratch all the time this one is comparable. It is a great time saver and tastes much better then just using the directions on the box.

text:
I was really nervous about this cake because of the cake mix amounts. My stores only carry 15.25 oz. cake  mixes. I bought the Betty Crocker Devil's Chocolate Cake mix. I added 3 oz. Of cake flour and about a half teaspoon of cocoa powder to compensate for the difference. Also, my pudding was only 3.9 oz. I didn't add anything to compensate for that. I followed the recipe exactly after that and it turned out great for me. It appears that everyone has really good results with this recipe, I'm curious if anyone else noticed these changes in cake mix amounts. It seems to be all cake mixes. And now I'm curious about the pudding too. I'll have to look when I go back to the store. Anyway, it turned out great and I'd make it again. I'm going to frost it with chocolate frosting and decorate it with chocolate curls!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This is a GREAT recipe. I did make the following changes...instead of chocolate cake mix I used rotini noodles - about two cups - instead of pudding I brown a half pound of hamburger (seasoned with cajun seasoning, onions, garlic, and pepper). I boiled/drained the noodles and mixed with the beef. In place of sour cream and vegetable oil I used a jar of pizza sauce and instead of a cup of water I used a cup of milk (though water would have probably been fine). And instead of chocolate chips I used sliced pepperoni. And finally instead of eggs I topped with cheese. Baked 350 until the cheese was bubbly. Delish!! Thanks for the great recipe!!! Happy kids at my place!! They ask me to make this again and again!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this cake over twenty times in the last couple years. I only do it on holidays and birthdays. I usually make the cake and we have a few pieces. I send it off with my husband to work to save me the calories.  Everyone at my husbands work asks when the next cake will arrive. The only thing I do different is leave the chocolate chips out and follow the recipe to a tee. I find the chips burned at the bottom of the pan the first time I did it and it was (just like the title) too much chocolate. But leaving the chips out made it just right. I also use the cream cheese frosting from allrecipes and its the perfect match. Over the years I have done different flavors. For yellow, white, and multi color cakes I use vanilla pudding instead of the chocolate pudding.  It comes out perfect every time. I am not an expert baker but everybody at my husbands work thinks I am. lol Thank you to whoever submitted this recipe.  It will be a family recipe for years to come. I found this recipe amazing and easy to follow.

It is an awesome recipe. I made it the first time following the recipe exactly but in my case it had way too much chocolate so for the next time I made little changes that I wanna share. First of all, instead of chocolate pudding mix I used butterscotch pudding mix and it really help with all the chocolate. Other thing is that i also eliminated the chocolate chips, and this time when my family tasted it they thought it was great because it didn't have all of that chocolate but it still remained a chocolate cake. But the original recipe is still amazing and it deserves 5 stars.

text:
This cake is absolutely delicious. My family can't get enough...I made a few variations:
I used 15.25 ounces of triple fudge cake mix and 3 ounces of fudge cake, I've also made it with 15.25 ounces fudge and 3 ounces dark chocolate. I substituted the oil with unsweetened applesauce, and to smooth out the batter I added about 2 TBS of milk and about 1 TB of coconut oil. I like to use the Satiny Glaze over it and I finally garnish with some fresh strawberries.

text:
This is a very easy cake to make and it has been a huge hit. I  have made 4 of these in 5 days if that tells you anything. The recipe can be altered to make it a little healthier, which I did on 2 of the cakes I made. I have even had a co worker tell me she would be happy to pay me to make her one. True to the name, it is very chocolatey. A cold glass of milk is all you need  for this wonderful cake. It is definitely my favorite new recipe.

text:
This is my go to recipe for decorated cakes. I do reduce the oil to about 3/4 cup. Also makes great cupcakes but because of the high amount of oil it soaks through the papers. For cupcakes I use 1/2 cup oil, though one of these days I'm going to substitute it with applesauce and see what happens. I love to pair this with Georgetown Cupcakes buttercream recipe and add a bit of flavored creamer (Samoa GS Cookie is the best) for an amazing flavor.

text:
Made this for my birthday, first bundt cake ever!  It was excellent, and i followed the recipe with the exception of using olive oil (all i had on hand). Could not taste it.I also replaced the water with coffee as another reviewer suggested.
Iced it with Satiny Chocolate Glaze and followed another reviewers suggestion to heat the butter and corn syrup first then add the chocolate chips, works fantastic, no microwaving needed. Garnished with local strawberries, now in season, which adds a fresh burst of flavour with such a rich cake. Love it!

text:
I made this cake for my beloved boyfriend who came home from a school trip no longer than an hour ago, and for my dad (who has a sweet tooth). I followed the cake recipe exactly... except for greasing the pan... I forgot to do that. But in the end, the boys loved it and the cake itself turned out perfect (the excess oil other reviewers mentioned was actually what saved the cake). So now I know that I don't need to grease the bundt pan if I use the amount of oil the recipe calls for. Now I have to pawn the rest of it off at school tomorrow because of the celiac in my family, and I'm sure the cake will be a huge hit.

text:
I never take the time to write any reviews, but this one is definitely work a review! This cake is absolutely DELICIOUS!!!! My husband isn't a chocolate fan and he has already ate half the pan. I didn't make any changes to the recipe aside from the fact that I used a regular glass cake pan because I didn't have a bundt pan. It took exactly 55 minutes to bake in a regular glass pan, but of course I checked it throughout just to make sure I wouldn't burn it. I topped it with the satin glaze also on this website and spread a cup of semi-sweet chocolate chips on top. ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS and by far the best chocolate cake I've ever had; especially with some vanilla ice cream.

text:
I've made this cake many times now and it always comes out really well. This time I used yellow cake mix, coconut cream pudding mix, sweetened, flaked coconut, semi-sweet chocolate chips and a 1/4t. rum flavor. I made a boo-boo and forgot the sour cream... we took the cake back out of the oven, mixed in the sour cream and voila! It was now chocolate coconut cream cake. The semi-sweet pieces had just been in there long enough to melt. Once it was cooled completely I drizzled bottled warmed up caramel ice cream topping and then sprinked the whole thing with toasted coconut and almonds. Even the big BOO-BOO didn't factor in to it's deliciousness!!! Really Decadent to the MAX!

text:
I have to admit, I wondered if this recipe would work and not only did it work, it was a smashing success at a luncheon at work.  I used the Satiny Chocolate Glaze recipe for the topping.  I also chose to process some White Chocolate Chips as the "Sprinkle" on top of the cake.  It was perfect!  The white of the White Chocolate Chips contrasted perfectly with the dark cake.  The cake was very moist, not dry at all.  I wound up cooking it for 55 minutes in my oven.  I will definitely make again as I am a chocolate lover and look for delicious recipes to make.  
The video showed the user making it with a wire whisk on the mixer.  But I used the flat blade and it worked just fine.  Next time I make it, I will try using the White Chocolate Chips as the base in the Satiny Glaze.

text:
I loved this recipe, as did my bf, my parents, and my co-workers.  I made my in a 8 loaf mini-loaf pan: it makes about 20 loafs and takes about 22 min to bake them.  Fill each mini loaf spot a little more than half way with batter and just put the extra batter in the fridge while baking.  Then on each loaf I put about 4 chocolate chips which then melted and made a nice smooth chocolate center.  The regular size chips worked great, esp when reheated in the microwave.  Stayed moist for days, if they last that long!

Second time I used coffee instead of water and peanut butter chips instead of chocolate. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my first review - this cake is so good I had to write!!  I made it for our Christmas dinner dessert.  What a hit!!  My 15 year old grandson had a large piece and then asked if he could take a piece home for later. I made some changes after reading other reviews.  I used 1/2 cup oil and 1/2 cup cream/milk.  I had the cream so I used it.  I also used the mini chocolate chips which I very lightly dusted with flour (2 tsp).  I used 2 small boxes of sugar free instant chocolate pudding.  I was worried it would be just too too sweet, but it wasn't.  It was heavy, moist and delicious. For the frosting, I slightly warmed a can of chocolate fudge frosting and "poured" it over the top to drip down the sides.  Then I drizzled butterscotch and white fudge over that.  Heavenly!!

text:
It's too much chocolate for my taste but it's very moist!  What gives it's moisture is definetely the sour cream and pudding mixture.  I tried a recipe from this idea as suggested one reviewer. I made cupcakes out of it.  The cupcakes were absolutely incredible, family is pleased with this recipe! Recipe  goes like this 
-box of white cake
- vanilla pudding mixture (jello trade) 110 g (bigger isnt found no where) 
- 1 cup of fat free sour cream
- half cup oil 
- half cupmilk 
- 4 eggs
and most important a box of fresh rasberry! (add them after mixing the whole mixture up so they don't get broken , better taste)
 TRUST ME it's delicious :)

I took it to work to celebrate our associate pastor's 1 year ordination anniversary, and he and all of my coworkers loved it! Thanks for a great, quick recipe!

text:
I LOVED this cake.  My husband and stepson, thought it was good, but not fabulous.  I did modify the recipe a little bit.  I was out of sour cream, so I substituted 6 oz of vanilla Greek yogurt (one of the single serving cups).  I also added 1 cup strong brewed coffee in place of the water.  This was an increase of 1/2 cup of liquid.  My batter was REALLY thick, even with the additional liquid.  It was so beautiful out of the pan I didn't add any glaze or powdered sugar.  This is my new favorite cake and will definitely make it again and again :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was one of the best chocolate cakes I've ever had and it was so easy.  I used a both a square and round eight inch pan (for a heart for my girlfriend and my anniversary) and mini chocolate chips to melt easier.  I also added the "Satiny Chocolate Glaze" recipe from this site which is just 3/4 cup semisweet chocolate chips, 3 tbs butter, and a splash of light corn syrup in pyrex in the microwave for 45 sec with 1/4 teaspoon vanilla extract after heated.  Finally, I added a raspberry glaze on the plate and I really think it enhanced it that much more.  For the raspberry glaze, I just took some raspberry preserves and added a bit of water and light corn syrup. 

Enjoy!!

text:
Made this cake yesterday and it's phenomenal!!! I'm not sure if I've EVER had better chocolate cake and I am a picky chocolate-cake gal. Followed almost everything w/ the exception of a few items because I use a fancy, very intricate bundt pan with a lot of detail and didn't want to chance a cake that was too gooey or slightly crispy (higher baking temp) for my ornate pan. Used only 1/2 c oil. Used only 1 cup MINI choco chips. And I baked it at 325 degrees for 55 minutes. It tured out beautifully and tasted truly terrific. I simply dusted w/ powdered sugar and added strawberries to the top.

Everyone RAVED about this cake! I can't wait to make it again! Thanks Denise, great job!

text:
Great cake. Made it for my family the other night and they all loved it. Followed the recipe exactly and it came out perfect. I was a little hesitant about leaving a cake in a Bundt pan for 1 1/1 hours since I thought for sure it wouldn't come out of the pan without a struggle. I actually tried to take it out sooner but it wouldn't  budge. Waited until 1 1/2 hours were up and it came out of the pan without sticking. Will be making this again.

text:
I definitely give this recipe five stars! It was extremely easy to make. I followed the recipe exactly as written. I allowed it to cool for 40 min, then jiggled my bundt pan to see if it was ready,(and it was), and when I turned it over it was perfect! I used Duncan Hines Devils Food for the cake mix, and Jello brand chocolate pudding. I recommend PAM spray with flour for baking (ESPECIALLY WITH BUNDT CAKES). My guests absolutely loved the cake. I dusted a light coating of powdered sugar on it, and then served with vanilla bean icecream. Absolute decadence!!

text:
This cake was great! I baked it for my boyfriend for Valentine's Day, and the both of us as well as his parents agreed it was the best cake we've ever had. I accidentally bought a 15oz box of cake mix, but I used 3/4C. Oil and sprinkled in some flour. The cake batter was very spongy and thick; not very "batter"-y like pancake mix or other cupcake mixes I've made. I baked it in two round pans. Like the top review said, the chocolate chips can be deceiving when you test for your cake to be done. I will definitely be making this cake again!

text:
1 (18.25 ounce) package devil's food cake mix is now obsolete. The cake boxes have changed in size since this recipe was posted.  The 18.25 oz. mix is now 16.25.  Still followed the recipe and the cake is still wonderful.  
Also used the Chocolate Ganache posted from "INGRIDEVOGEL" to Allrecipes as a topping, minus the rum. Drizzled about half to the top of the cake.
Both recipes are very easy. 
Thanks to Denise and Ingridevogel for posting both of these.

text:
Like this needs another review, right? Just have to say that I made this cake for the first time, using red velvet cake mix and about a cup and a half semi-sweet chocolate chips. other than that, I followed the recipe and amounts exactly (using a 3.9 box of chocolate pudding...wasn't sure there, and topped with the satiny chocolate glaze), and this cake should be called "the best chocolate cake ever." Yum! Perfect taste and texture...very moist, and is great served at room temperature or straight out of the fridge. It's a definite keeper as a base recipe. I am looking forward to trying other flavor variations of this cake. :)

text:
I made this for Christmas Eve dinner's dessert.  Although I cook and bake all of the time, it was actually my first chocolate cake to make from scratch.  Everyone loved it!  And I loved making it!  I have trouble frosting cakes so drizzling chocolate on a perfectly formed bundt cake worked fabulously and was very impressive.  I followed the directions exactly, after watching the wonderfully helpful and comforting associated video.  The only thing I did was melt half milk chocolate and half semisweet morsels in a little cup, transferred the melted chocolate to a ziploc with the corner cut off, and drizzled chocolate on top to make it look like one of the pictures-- this part is non-negotiable!  This recipe is simply awesome.

text:
Deee-licious!! I tried this for my mother's birthday. I made it in two 8" round pans, so it only took about 35 minutes to cook. I stacked the two cakes, put a mixture of cool whip/cocoa/ powdered sugar in between it all, and topped it with a simple chocolate glaze. Decorated it with mnm's, and voila... a delicious, extremely chocolatey cake. It was good the first day, and it was good the second day. Didn't last longer than three days in a house of three people!

text:
Don't look any further. Just do this. It's amazing. My family raved and raved about how good it was! My 90-year-old grandfather, who's probably had many, many cakes in his lifetime, said it was the best chocolate cake he's ever tasted. No one will ever know that you used a cake mix. I don't have a big enough Bundt pan, so I used a round springform pan, greased and floured with cocoa powder. Baked at 350 for about 60-65 minutes. Like many of the reviewers, I made Satiny Chocolate Glaze and poured it on top for an incredible finish. AMAZING.

text:
I have been making this wonderful cake for years with just a few minor changes. Instead of 1 cup of oil and 1/2 cup of warm water, I use 1/2 cup of oil and a 1/2 cup of water. I use a small package of instant chocolate pudding and mini chocolate chips. I have made this cake many times using mini loaf pans to give for Christmas presents to neighbors and friends. This cake is very delicious and moist and freezes well.

text:
used 12 oz bag of mini semisweet chocolate chips instead of 2 cups regular sized semisweet chocolate chips.  (they're lighter & dont sink to the bottom as bad - so they hold their "place" throughout the cake more & melt evenly throughout.)

DEFINITELY a keeper.  AWESOME, MOIST cake.  probably the most moist cake i have ever made.  DELICIOUS.

1889633
Display Name:
Sierra A. W.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Today will be the third time I am making this cake. The first time I didn't really read the reviews and had to deal with the chocolate chips sinking to the bottom (top) of the bundt cake. The second time around, I read the reviews and came out with the winning idea of the mini chocolate chips. Also, when I make a cake (especially a doctored one like this) the best way I have found to get the cake to come out lovely is to grease the pan (with whatever you feel comfortable with) and then take a little bit of the dry mix and coat the pan with that (just roll it around in the pan and then add it back to the dry mix. It does WONDERS, you just HAVE to let the cake cool. You must, you must, you must! You can use the full amount of oil and 2 cups of chocolate chips and there won't be any "crusty sides" or "sinking chocolate."

text:
This turned out great, reminded me of a very good brownie - only much larger :) I followed the recipe mostly, although noticed that it called for 18.25oz cake mix, and 5.9oz pudding mix - what I bought at the store was 16.5oz cake mix, and 3.9 oz pudding mix - so I reduced the oil to 3/4 cup as another reviewer noted, I also chopped up the chocolate chips in a food processor and it turned out perfect! I used the "satiny chocolate glaze" (also from this site) as well, and everyone loved it..

text:
I have used this recipe for over a year now. LOVE IT. You can substitute Mayo or Miracle Whip for the Sour cream if you need to. It tastes the same. All three of those ingredients are to make sure it stays moist. You can use a cup of any in any cake recipe. You can also plastic wrap your cake after it cools and freeze it. Then just pull it out and set it on the counter still wrapped until it thaws usually 3 hours.

This was a huge success.  I used a store brand mix since most of the name brands are no longer 18.25 ounces.  I followed the recipe exactly using regular size chips, I did hold a few back to sprinkle on top since someone said they sank.  I didn't seem to have an issue with that though. I made cherry crisp for sme gathering and some people ate the two together.  We served it with ice cream.

text:
Super.  I'm an American living in London so I my first problem was cake mixes are scarce, but my nearby large store did have them.  I had to do without chocolate chips (as they come in tiny bags with high price tags) and thought I'd have to do without pudding (which they don't have here) but found one in the cabinet we brought from home.  Oh the troubles I face here ;)

I halved the oil and added a mashed banana.  It was perfect.  I also "Britishized" it by using 2 round cake pans and did a layer of jelly ("jam") in the middle and powdered sugar on top.  It pained me to skip out on the frosting but actually this was delicious.  Will def do again.

text:
5 stars!  Awesome cake and SOOO easy. Doesn't taste like it was from a box of cake mix and pudding mix and if I hadn't told anyone at the party how I made it everyone would have thought that it had been slaved over for HOURS!  Every person that had cake commented on how good it was.  I used the Satiny Chocolate Glaze as other reviewers suggested (from allrecipes).  Since it's summer, I put the cake (covered) in the fridge in fear that it would just start melting once I put the glaze on, but since the glaze is made of chocolate chips it got very hard on top, so I had to let it sit out for about 20-30 minutes before serving.  I don't think I'll put it in the fridge the next time I make it.  Especially if it's not in the Summer. Other than that wouldn't do anything differently. Thinking about trying with different cake mixes and pudding flavors as others suggested.  Wonderful recipe!

text:
This is a five star recipe! However I did not follow the recipe as written (I know what you're thinking!). I did not want to go to the store so I used what I had. I used a 3.4 oz box of vanilla pudding mix and a 6 oz. container of fat free plain greek yogurt instead of the chocolate pudding and sour cream. I also scaled down the wet ingredients a tad to compensate for the decreased amount of dry ingredients. It turned out amazing! I made them into cupcakes, baked them for about 14 minutes on convection. They turned out like the "perfect" cupcake! They rose nicely and were moist and chocolatey!

text:
This is an awesome cake. It came out so moist!  When it said to pour the batter into the pan, mine just sort of flopped into the pan. lol It kind of scared me that I had did it wrong but the cake turned out great. So if you are wondering if you did it right when the batter flops into the pan, dont worry. Mine did the same. When eating the cake for fathers day, all i could think was that the cake needed a more chocolate flavor. I found that the flavor was almost subdued. I am going to try this recipe again with a different chocolate cake. Maybe a milk chocolate. I might add Chocolate liquor or something that will boost the flavor.  Otherwise this a great recipe. Thanks.

text:
I followed the recipe exactly. It baked beautifully and looked great, and even tasted all right. But it was too oily for my tastes. There was a very noticeable film of oil on the plate or fingers after eating it. It was too much for me - and I have a high tolerance for fatty foods.

I WOULD use this recipe again (I want to!), but I would follow the advice of others and DEFINITELY halve the oil - and maybe add applesauce to replace the liquid.

The only thing I did different was I grated Chocolate bark in the batter instead of using chocolate chips, I always double the recipe and find the chips sink to the bottom of my 4 inch deep pans and tend to burn.

text:
I used this recipe to make a dinosaur-shaped cake for my son's second birthday. I followed the recipe exactly, except that I used mini semisweet chocolate chips. It came out beautifully. Making the cake was the simple part. I baked one day, iced the next, and served on the third. Everyone loved the flavor, including my 2-year-old. I will make this again, though I think I'll choose a less labor-intensive preparation.

I've made this one at least 15 times now since I first tried it - it is our go-to cake when chocolate cake is requested.  I always use a bag of mini chocolate chips so they don't sink.  They disperse evenly and perfectly in the cake.  Otherwise, I make it just as per recipe.  It's an amazing cake!  Dense and almost brownie-like which is perfect for my family who much prefers brownies over most cakes.

text:
Been making this cake for awhile now to rave reviews, always a hit and you can keep the ingredients on hand. You can try variations of cake mix/ pudding (yellow cake mix w/ vanilla pudding, choc cake w/  cookies n cream pudding, etc.). Using 2 small boxes of pudding (vs 1 lg box) works fine, and mini chips DO work the best. I have omitted the chips before and sometimes get a cake that falls, sometimes does not??

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/121.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I give this 5 stars, it was delicious. I read all the lower reviews, just to see if people changed it. Well I used 3/4 cup oil, and could have used the whole cup, not that its dry or anything. (: I made mine with a butterscotch sauce. I made it with 1 3/4 cups heavy whipping cream, 2 1/2 tbsp powdered sugar, and a full bag (12 oz.) of butterscotch chips. I brought the heavy cream to a simmer, took it off the heat and added the chips, stirred until it was almost melted, and put it back on low heat and stirred until it bubbled, added the sugar and stirred about 4 more minutes. Then I took it off and put it in a container and put it in the fridge for about 1 hour and glazed the cake with it. (: Delicious. And this recipe is so versatile! I love this recipe. So does my Mom in law, and my son! :D

text:
This cake was awesome!!  There were some baker-errors though (oops!) so there are defintely things that I would change. I used a regular circle cake pan and adjusted the cooking time...which I won't be doing next time because the center was still un-done when I took it out.  However, even with that mistake my 2 pregnant girlfriends LOVED it...as did I.  The sour cream really helps cut the richness and that chocolate overload taste.  And, as other reviewers suggested I used mini choco chips.  This was fantastic...I will definitely be making this again!!

This is an excellent cake, especially when combined with the Satiny Chocolate Glaze recipe on the site. Baking time should be closer to 50 than 55 minutes. (NB. The cake goes from perfectly done to burnt within a very small time window. Beware.)

Absolutely Delicious.I have not make box cakes in years, but after reading reviews decided to give it a try.  Amazing flavors and decadent is all I can say!
After reading reviews I did purchase the "decadent chocolate" mix which comes with extra goodness and the outcome was outrageous.  This is a "soft cake" so follow directions and allow to rest in pan several hours before transferring to plate.  I served with fresh whipped cream with a splash of Kahlua. This will be one of my favorite recipes. Great flavor, and so easy to put together.

Ok, so after reading almost half of the reviews I was hesitant to use the full cup of oil.  I used only 3/4 cup and 1/4 milk and this actually just tasted like a boxed cake mix.  Use the full cup of oil!!  I added 3/4 cup mini chips and 1/2 cup of peppermint chip for holiday flare and the small bits of peepermint  you get are great!  Was expecting a fabulous cake and would say its only so so.

text:
This recipe is amazing! I used mini chocolate chips and it's a little chocolate in every bite. I made it without chocolate chips and it was delicious but the chocolate chips really makes a difference. 

If I make it with chocolate chips, I don't use icing. I once mixed all the ingredients without the eggs, I simply forgot. I then added in the eggs and this method gave me a very moist cake.

I am going to use this formula for all box cake mixes!

text:
AHHHH-MAZING!!! I am not a baker.  I am a cook.  Most things I bake never turn out well.  I followed this recipe exactly, and it is AH-Mazing.  I will be making this cake again and agian.  The used a Duncan Hines Creamy Choc icing, I warmed it on the stoved and spooned it all over the cake.  It made it extra moist.  I also used mini-chips intstead of choc chips (I don't know if that made a difference or not, but the mini chips were completely melted into the cake).  I'm sure serving it warm with vanilla icecream would be divine.  Thanks for the recipe!!!

region:

country:
None
text:
I was afraid of using 1 cup of oil because there are a number of reviews that say it really is just too much. So, I a little over 3/4 cup. I don't have a bundt pan and I didn't want to use a regular rectangular 9X13, so I used a cupcake tin. A half hour for a tray of 12 was perfect. Also, I forgot to mix the chips in, so I put them on top. It was good, would have been so much better if the chips were throughout, as the recipe calls for; would have been more choco-riffic! Also, I made a white chocolate glaze and drizzled it on the top. They were a hit! I will definitely make it again ;D

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I cut the oil to 3/4 cup and added 1 cup of chopped strawberries (folded in after the cake was mixed) along with the choc. chips (but I only used about 1 cup of chips).  Sliced it, surrounded it with fresh sliced strawberries, and drizzled a little bit of strawberry sauce (fresh strawberrys pureed with sugar to tastes) over it when I served it.  Fabulous, lots of compliments, and many requests for the recipe.  Don't add any frosting or powdered sugar- the sauce will add that bit of sugar kick, and the strawberries really set off the chocolate taste.

text:
I had a box of devils food cake mix and no frosting, so I decided to make this. Def does not need frosting. This is how I modified it with what I had available, I only had 1-3 oz package of instant choc pudding mix, 1/3 cup low fat sour cream, 1/3 cup plain Greek yogurt, 1/2 vege oil, 1/3 milk, 3 eggs, 1 egg whites, 1 cup semisweet choc chip, 1 cup white choc chips. So I cut the calories back unintentionally in some areas, but you would NEVER know it! Excellent!

Well, we girls do love our chocolate and this cake won't disappoint.  Be very aware: it is very rich!  This recipe is so requested, I make sure I have the ingredients on hand at all times so when I am asked to bring something, I can say 'yes' without delay on what to make.  I have experimented with different cake mixes and baking chip flavors and all experiments turned out above and beyond my expectation--and never once did my husband get a left over slice of cake or crumbs left on the cake plate.   Be creative in experimenting with this recipe, it is fun and surprising how much you will learn about the blend-ability of ingredient flavors.

This is a DELICIOUS cake for being so easy. I followed the recipe, only thing I did was reduce the choc. chips to 1 cup. I was worried it would be way too chocolatey but it wasn't and next time I will add the full amount.  For some reason in my bundt pan it took about 10 minutes longer to cook than recipe states. didn't have problems with the edges being crunchy however they were slightly drier than the middle which was no big deal and totally not noticable. I drizzled some white icing that was sold in a bottle next to the Devil's Food cake mix. That added a nice finish. I think I'll use this recipe for my son's 3rd b-day party!

Maybe I did something wrong, the cake came out very crumbly. The flavor was OK, not what I was hoping for. I brought this for a lunch party at my friends house with lot of kids, had plenty leftover. text:
Wonderful!  Made exactly as directed, except using mini chocolate chips instead of regular chips, as someone else had suggested.  I used an electric mixer, and the batter was so thick, I thought I had made a mistake in using the mixer instead of a whisk.  It baked beautifully though!  I also inadvertently bought devil's food cake with pudding in the mix, so I worried how it would turn out.  It was wonderful!  I also used the Satiny Chocolate Glaze, as someone else had suggested.  It didn't drizzle as nicely as I had hoped, but it didn't look bad and it was quite tasty.  Next time, I might try using shortening in the glaze instead of butter, in hopes that the glaze will be a bit smoother.  This will probably be my dessert of choice for potlucks.  At a recent gathering, everyone wanted the recipe.  It was nice to be able to refer them to this website.

text:
Based on previous reviews, I thought this cake was going to be a magical revelation for my taste buds, but it was not. This is a very good chocolate cake but I have had better. I will keep this recipe and make it again however next time I will add vanilla (I'm actually surprised the recipe didn't call for it). I made this is an medium sized football shaped cake pan and it needed to bake on the lowest shelf for about an hour and a half. If you're looking for an outrageously easy cake to make that's chocolatey and moist, this is for you!

text:
This cake is the BOMB!!  I covered this cake in homemade peanut butter frosting and it was a HUGE hit at our party.  I am bringing it to a superbowl party tonight and a casino party next weekend.   I make the peanut butter frosting with a stick of margarine, stick of butter (both at room temperature) about a cup of peanut butter, powdered sugar and a few tablespoons of milk.  Blend until you get the desired consistency. I like it fluffy.

I made this for my husband to take to work and another for my work. I used a bag of nestle mint chocolate chips in place of the semi sweet. It turned out fantastic. I also made a lemon one using yellow cake mix instead of choc and used lemon pudding in place of chocolate. Then melted some cream cheese and mixed in confectioner's sugar to make a glaze to drizzle over the top. OMG! It went over better than the mint chocolate. All though both went quick. Thanks for a great recipe and base for other flavors. It's definitely a keeper.

text:
This has been a family favorite for over 30 years with a little difference: 1 yellow cake mix 1 small choc fudge instant pudding 3/4 c water 3/4 c oil 3 eggs 1 c sour cream 2 c choc chips Mix all but chips, then stir in chips.  Spray bundt pan, sprinkle with sugar not flour.  No icing needed and better the next day.  Freezes will also.  Enjoy!

text:
I was looking for a dessert to bring to party and this one looked too good to be true. I stayed true to the recipe....although I made it lighter. I used egg beaters in place of the eggs, light sour cream and in place of the oil I used sun sweet lighter bake. I did add 2 tablespoons of oil for a little fat.  I used mini chips as suggested by others, just not quite as much. In the end it came out rich, moist and when I sprinkled powdered sugar on it ....gorgeous! I can't imagine how rich it is with the full fat ingredients. It certainly wasn't diet food how I made it...but no one missed the fat!  Great recipe....tonight I am making cupcakes for my son's class using the same recipe and am hoping it works out well!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cake is very easy to prepare, and so rich! I did make some changes to the original recipe; I used 1/2 cup canola oil and 1/2 cup unsweetened applesauce, and added two  packages of chocolate instant pudding. The cake will puff up quite a bit while baking, due to the extra pudding, but will return to normal size once it is out of the oven. I baked this for 60 minutes at 350F. I also used a full package (approx. 2 cups) of semi-sweet chocolate chunks instead of the morsels. I have also made this cake in a 13x9-inch baking dish--330F for about 45-50 minutes. The result was the softest, moistest, most flavorful chocolate Bundt cake I have ever made. It does not need icing; a dusting of powdered sugar is enough. Everyone in my family thought this was delicious!

Display Name:
Kenzie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/433199.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely wonderful! I have made this cake twice to date-once for a church function and once again today for a family Thanksgiving celebration-with superb results each time. I didn't quite like the idea of using all these ready made ingredients so I altered things a bit to make it my own. I omitted the sour cream and pudding mix, choosing to make a homemade chocolate pudding(1/3 cup cocoa powder, 1/2 cup white sugar, 3 tablespoons cornstarch, 1 cup half&half, 1/2 cup water, 1/2 cup milk; made in the microwave. 3 minutes initially then in 1 minute intervals, stirring for 2 to 4 minutes between cycles) instead. I also reduced the vegetable oil to 3/4 cup. The chocolate chips were a mixture of milk and white because I wanted a sweeter flavor and greater richness (semisweet don't melt as well as the other chips). Divine when paired with a white chocolate glaze (Satiny Chocolate Glaze from this site using white chips instead of semisweet). I grated some white chocolate as well as placing whole chips on top of the cake. The contrast is beautiful! This cake will be a star among all events I attend requiring dessert. Thanks so much!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-11-24T00:06:25.51
helpfulCount:

userID:
498224
Display Name:
Caren
isPro:
False
followersCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good recipe, especially if you are in a super hurry to get this in the oven, it whips up in no time. I used an organic basic chocolate food cake mix.   I only had a non-instant vanilla pudding mix, so I used that. It thickened up nicely while cooking.   I didn't have sour cream so I used mayonnaise (1 cup) - yummy!  I reduced the 4 eggs to 3 because of the mayo, 2/3 cup of oil, also because of the mayo. Ran my knife over the chocolate chips a few times so they would melt into the batter nicely while it cooked. They did. I started with a batter I thought was a touch runny, but I went ahead and cooked it anyway in a 9 x 13 glass pan for nearly an hour at as close to 350? as I can get my old oven to heat up to. It set up better than I had expected. I let it cool in the pan, then I decorated with my standard chocolate frosting: Whip together 3C Icing Sugar, 3Tbsp good quality Cocoa powder, 3Tbsp Butter, a generous Tbsp of Vanilla, 3-4 Tbsp slowly added Heavy cream. I'm sure you can use any combination of cake & pudding mixes, or eve trade the chocolate chips in for white chocolate, butterscotch, or even peanut butter chocolate chips, and still come out with an easy hit and crowd favorite. I'm using this recipe next for a spice cake made with vanilla pudding mix & white chocolate chips, covered in icing made with baileys instead of milk.  ;)

text:
I've used this recipe many times, all fail proof. Last night, I realised that I only had 2 eggs and didn't have any sour cream. I used 3/4 cup milk with 3/4 tablespoon of vinegar and 1/3 cup of butter (approx. 75 grams) to replace the sour cream (or you could use 3/4 butter milk and 1/3 cup of butter). I also only made do with two eggs, and the cake turned out superbly! It's not has dense as the original recipe, but the taste wasn't compromised!

country:

text:
Made this for a dinner party and it was a huge hit. I followed the recipe except did what some others did and subsitute the oil for applesauce. This was also the first time I made a bundt cake so wasn't sure how it would come out. I also use one bag of regular sized chocolate chips and a 1/2 bag of mini chips. Used the rest to sprinkle on top of the cake. The cake batter was really thick, like brownie batter. I had to bake it for about 1 hour. I cheated and used store bought white chocolate glaze and went overboard on it. The cake was like a cross of a dense chocolate cake or a lighter brownie. I was joking with my dh and said that I could make the white version (white cake, vanilla pudding, and white chocolate chips) and he dared me since he loved this cake so much. I think I'll stick with the chocolate version. You know what they say about women and their chocolate...

text:
A few weeks back I made this for an office potluck. I made two cake layers and topped one with chocolate satin glaze (which I purchased) and the other with whipped vanilla frosting.  All of us agreed we liked the chocolate satin glaze over the whipped vanilla frosting. The glaze really brings out the other chocolate layered flavors of the cake.  Overall, the cake with glaze topping was a huge hit, but not the cake topped with frosting. And no one asked for the recipe and the frosting topped cake was not really touched. Chocolate glaze prep is a keeper.  I did use milk instead of water. Next time, I will melt the chips a bit, then add the melted chips to the batter. I think I would prefer the evenness of the chocolate throughout the cake, instead of bits of chocolate.

text:
Incredible: As per other reviews, I only used 1/2 cup oil, 1 1/2 cup choc chips & 1/3 cup milk.  I actually baked in 2x9" rounds alternating top/bottom shelf for about 50 min...cake was perfect.  I always bake top/bottom shelf alternating..seems to turn out cakes/cupcakes perfectly every time with less cooking time.  I used Satiny Chocolate Glaze on top, and filled the layers with Magnolia Bakery Vanilla Buttercream frosting and sprinkled crushed semi-sweet choc chips on top.  BEST CAKE OVERALL - Simply Incredible!

This is such a great recipe. Thanks to another review, I've tried this with vanilla cake and white chocolate pudding mix, as well as other flavours. The vanilla and white chocolate pudding is awesome, I just learned not to use white chocolate chips. I've now made this at least a dozen times for birthday cakes in various shaped bundt pans. I've done several versions of this with the white mix, white pudding and divvied the dough into multiple bowls, tinted each one a bright colour with paste food colouring, then spooned the batter into the pan to make rainbow cakes. This makes an awesome cake for any shaped pan.

I baked it in 3 9in pans and frosted with a traditional chocolate frosting.  Unlike another reviewer I had no problems getting it out of the pan.  I greased and floured the pan before baking.  My teenage son who can usually eat 1/2 of a cake could only eat 1 slice because it is so rich.  Served it at a birthday party and everyone raved about the cake and even requested the recipe.

text:
It is no surprise this cake was delicious. There are thousands of reviews that say just that. I have made cakes from scratch and cakes from a box and this is the best of both. Not nearly as labor intensive asa from scratch cake, since you are using a cake mix, but absolutely moist and perfect. The first time I made this cake, I overcooked it a bit and it was a little dry. I kept sticking a toothpick in to check for doneness and I must have been hitting the melted chocolate chips. The second time I made it I kept with the suggested time. Do as others have suggested and use the mini chocolate chips. This will stay in the recipe box for birthdays and other special events.

Display Name:
SarahE

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
There are so many reviews of this recipe, I don't know if another one will make a difference.  I have made this several times now, and it is unbelievable!  It is extremely chocolaty.  People ALWAYS love it, many saying it is the best chocolate cake they have ever had.  It is soo moist!  I am a big believer in making things from scratch, but when you have a special occasion and are short on time, this can't be beat.  You really don't know it's from the box.  It's so easy, I feel guilty accepting the (numerous) compliments whenever I make it.  I used 1/2 C. oil and 1/2 C. milk for a less oily consistency, and yogurt instead of the sour cream (not trying to be healthier but sour cream was unavailable).  The cake doesn't really need a frosting, but this last time I topped it with chocolate ganache, and that added something.  Baked it in a 10x14(approx?) dish for 32 mins.  Works well with whipped cream or vanilla ice cream.  It is almost truly "too much chocolate cake"! :)

I read some reviews and I see people were asking if they can be done as cupcakes. Yes they can! I made them for my friend's 22nd birthday party and I topped it with vanilla buttercream frosting. The visual effect was stunning because the cupcakes looked white and silver (I used aluminum foil cupcake liners). everyone loved them and I got tons of compliments.  this cake rises a lot (at least as a cupcake). Use one tablespoon full of batter for each cupcake. I also took other reviewer's suggestions and used 3/4 cup of oil.  It's a keeper!

text:
Oh. My. Deliciousness. I've made this recipe 3x in the last month - I'm obsessed! And anyone who tastes this cake is too. The cake is super moist & doesn't need frosting (just a light dusting of powdered sugar).  The only thing I would change would be to use MINI chocolate chips. They melt & incorporate better, which makes for easier slicing.  Try mixing it up by using mint chips or cherry chips. Or make a new flavor by using yellow cake mix + butterscotch pudding + butterscotch chips... the possibilities are endless! And delicious!!

None
text:
I wanted a chocolate cake for my buddy's birthday.  He's a real chocolaholic.  This one was perfect!  I made it exactly as printed except I used another reviewers idea and used mini chips.  They were evenly distributed through out the entire cake instead of ending up at the bottom like bigger chips can do.  I used another persons icing made of 3 cups of coolwhip melted in the nuker with 8oz. of semi sweet bakers chocolate.  It made a nice semi hard coating on the inside of the bundt cake which I filled with sliced strawberries.  I used another recipe's idea and made a large flower on top of the cake with strawberry slices.  It was a big hit, and he took a picture to send to his mom.

text:
Very good for a quick cake.  I usually don't use boxed cake mix in my recipes because I prefer all ingredients from scratch.  But I made this cake very quickly on a week night and happened to have the cake mix in the pantry.  I didn't have any chocolate instant pudding so I used vanilla instant pudding instead and added 2 tablespoons of baking cocoa powder and a tsp of chocolate extract.  The cake is very moist and yummy.

text:
Made this last night for a covered dish dinner I was attending.  Being a chocoholic I was very excited about it.  I followed the recipe exactly, using mini-chocolate chips and light sour cream.  The batter was extremely thick spreading all the way up the beaters as I mixed it with my hand mixer.  I really enjoyed licking the beaters:-).  I did have to bake it about 10 extra minutes to make sure it was baked all the way through.  I sprinkled it with powder sugar.  Surprisingly, only two small slices were taken - I took the first piece to check it out.  I guess unless you don't like chocolate, this is not too much chocolate!  I probably will try it again, but, using substitutions to make it lighter version - applesauce, sugarfree pudding, egg substitute and light sour cream. This was good, but, not quite as good as my sister's chocolate, chocolate chip zucchini cake recipe.  However, my kids are very happy that I brought most of it home for them!

text:
I'm a cake decorator and have been using this recipe for a couple of years when asked to do a chocolate chip cake. Everyone raves about it. I prefer to make cakes from scratch, but this recipe is fantastic in a pinch. Doesn't taste like a boxed cake at all. It is a dense cake and holds up well. I use 1/2 cup of chocolate chips and it turns out moist having a nice chocolaty taste. My son-in-law who hates cake requests this one from me. He calls it the Otis Spunkmeyer cake.

text:
I made this cake for Christmas and I can honestly say that this is one of the best chocolate cakes I have ever eaten.  It has wonderful chocolate flavor, moist, lovely texture and keeps well.  Everyone loved this cake.  I would not change a thing.  I also used the Satiny Chocolate Glaze....to die for.  Next time tho, I will double the glaze.  It sets up nicely, not too firm, but  I think I would like to make it a little thicker on the cake.  Note that both the cake and the icing are not sickly sweet nor overly chocolatey.  Just rich and delicious.  I can see why this recipe won First Prize.  Well deserved.....Thank you for sharing Denise.

text:
It really is too much chocolate. I would consider making this for a group, but just to have around the house . . . One piece is enough to put you off chocolate for a while. And I'm not a wimp when it comes to chocolate. I didn't have enough eggs or pudding mix to make the bundt cake, so I halved the recipe and made 12 full cupcakes, no icing. I chopped (actually more like half-chopped, half-shaved) the chocolate chips with a large knife because I was concerned about them sinking to the bottom or not melting enough in the 25 minutes I baked the cupcakes. But they came out pretty much perfect. Might be good as a one-off dessert served with whipped cream or vanilla ice cream to temper the chocolate overload. A lot like pricier restaurant desserts.

text:
Tasted great. Very moist and chocolaty! Better yet, it was really easy to make. I did change the recipe to make it healthier according to the suggestions posted. I substituted low-fat plain yogurt for the sour cream, apple sauce for vegetable oil, found a fat-free chocolate pudding mix, and used 4 egg whites and 2 eggs as opposed to 4 eggs all together. Too bad I didn't have mini chocolate chips! I only had the normal sized ones laying around at the time, so they all sank to the bottom of the cake. I made a 2 layer 8" cake and 6 cupcakes.

text:
I forgot to rate this recipe when I first tried it years ago.  It is excellent.  If we are having ice cream with it, I top it with the "satiny glaze" recipe.  I have used this recipe for a fund raiser charging $25 each and sold $425 worth of cakes.  That should tell you something about how good it is.  As it gets closer to the holidays, people are asking me about ordering it.  Enjoy.

2/9/20 - I can't find an 18 oz box of cake mix any more.  My favorite, Duncan Hines, has shrunk down to 15.25 oz.  Three ounces isn't that big of a deal but I've gradually cut down the recipe.  Now I use 1/2 cup of oil and 3 eggs to get the same results.  Enjoy!

I decided to try this cake out last night and it was amazing! I used just a tiny bit less oil because of someone else's review but I can honestly say that the right amount of oil won't hurt it. This cake doesn't even need frosting! I had my mom pick up cream cheese frosting and we haven't even opened it. text:
Just plain wonderful and wouldn't change a thing.  The only thing to watch out for is to make sure you use the correct size bundt cake pan.  This cake rises quite a bit.  I didn't know how big my pan was and it turned out being too small and had to crank the temp down at the end and bake a little longer.  My problem though and nothing to do with the recipe!  Made with the Satiny Chocolate Glaze from this site, as others suggested.  It was chocolate perfection and so easy.  This ones a keeper!

text:
You can never have too much chocolate! This cake was amazing! I used 1/2 cup oil and 1/2 cup of 1% milk (1 cup of oil is a little much). Batter seems thick when you mix it but the cake come out perfect! I also used the mini chocolate chips to prevent them from sinking. Baked in bundt pan at 325 degrees for 55 minutes and it was perfect! Top of the cake had a little crispy bite and inside was so moist! And this cake is super easy to put together!

text:
Awesome cake!  I was a little skeptical about using a "doctored up" cake mix, but since I've had such bad luck with other chocolate cake recipes, I thought I'd try it.    I did follow other's suggestions and the only changed the oil to 1/2 cup and added 1/3 cup milk.  I also used mini chocolate chips. I only had 9" round cake pans so I split it between two. I left it in for 55 minutes and it was done perfect. I can't have a cake without frosting, so I used the "Whipped Cream-Cream Cheese Frosting" recipe from this site and sprinkled coconut on top. Everyone loved the cake and frosting combo as it wasn't too sweet.  No one could believe this came from a box mix!

text:
This is a great recipe, almost exactly the same as "Easy chocolate chip pound cake" which I have been making for years. The only difference I can see is that the other recipe uses yellow cake mix and only 3/4 cup of oil. Highly recommend reducing the oil in this recipe to 3/4 cup instead of a whole cup! This cake is easy to make and is always a hit anywhere I take it. REVISION: The other cake only calls for 1/2 cup chocolate chips and this one says use Two Cups!! I can see now why it's called Too Much Chocolate Cake! LOL
Review:

text:
Fantastic!  First time making this (not the last), so I followed the measurements exactly (nervous about the oil, but it was perfect).  I beat the egg whites separately until they got frothy, added the beaten yolks and the rest of the wet ingredients, and mixed slowly into the dry.  I would recommend preparing the pan with a dusting of dark cocoa.  I used a wheat flour and sugar mix for a carmel color.  Also used the satiny chocolate glaze from this site, and decorated with toasted walnut and mini chocolate chip pieces.  SO GOOD!!!  Buy vanilla ice cream to go with.

text:
Too bad there isn't a six star rating - I'd use it!!  My hubby smelled the chocolate in the air two hours after I took this cake out of the oven. He took a bite and closed his eyes. I had to lock it up to keep him from eating the entire thing!  :)  I used another reviewer's suggestion of 1/2 cup oil and 1/3 cup milk. I also baked it for 50 min at 330, then for another 10-15 at 350 and it was perfect - very moist! Extremely yummy recipe!

text:
Made this for a special occasion and was not let down!  I used mini chocolate chips and two 9 inch rounds so that the cooking time could be cut down and I could avoid the "crust" others talked about.  I used a whipped cream/cream cheese frosting and covered that with a chocolate ganache.  It was perfect.  I found crumbs the next day on the counter next to the empty cake plate as hubby couldn't keep his hands off it!  By far the best souped up cake mix recipe!

text:
After reading the reviews about this cake I decided to take it on. The ingredients seemed easy. Took the advice of the other reviewers and reduced the oil to 1/2 and added 1/3 cup of milk. I only added 1/2 cup of chocolate chips, was a little afraid it was going to be too chocolatly. Mixing the chocolate cips in a tsp. of flour helped them from sinking. Cooked it at 335 degrees for about 35 mins. In the end it turned out to actually be a very delicious cake that my family enjoyed.

This is an excellent recipe for basic chocolate cake.  I've made it several times as per the original instructions and it's come out very moist and delicious every time.  I covered it with a chocolate ganache recipe from this site.  Today I am making a 4 layer cake with peanut butter frosting in between the layers of the chocolate cake and then covering with chocolate frosting from the Hershey's Dutch Chocolate tin. Great go-to recipe for chocolate cake.  Never fails to impress.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
When I first mixed up this cake I wasn't so sure, it was awfully thick and I had to push it down into the pan.  I was sure that I had done something wrong - 1400 great reviews doesn't lie.  Anyway, it came out so unbelievably delicious.  Even better the second day.  I used sugar free pudding, low fat sour cream, and apple sauce instead of oil and it was still unbelievable.  I brought about half the cake into work and it didn't even last the morning.  Yummy.  Sidenote: I made this for my dads birthday and he has a gluten allergy so I tried to sub in gluten free cake mix - the dang thing never set.  I tried to bake it longer but it ended up burning.  This is just an FYI in case anyone tries to swap out cake mixes, give yourself some time to experiment instead of procrastinating (like me) and then scrambling at the last minute to throw together a plain ol' cake from the gluten free cake mix instructions.

This cake is fantastic. I made it with a German chocolate cake mix and the mini chocolate chips. I also added about 2TBS of chocolate syrup in with the 1/2 cup of water. There was so much cake batter though that I filled up my bunt cake pan and a round cake pan. I had no chocolate frosting so I added some chocolate syrup to some vanilla frosting to put in between the layers of cake and I then I added coconut pecan frosting to the rest of it. It is sooo good. I will certinaly make this again.

text:
mmmmm..... this cake is dangerous!!!! After I finished my first slice, I wanted to sit with the whole cake in front of me and eat it all by myself!!!!lol!!! This is a very simple cake that comes out perfect! I used what I had in my pantry- German Chocolate cake mix and only 1 cup of chocolate chips.. otherwise I follow the reciepe to the T. I served it with a berry sauce on top (YUM) 2 cups chopped berries(I used strawberries but I think next time I'll try raspberries!!!) 1/4 cup sugar, 1/4 cup water, 1 Tbl lemon juice, and 1 tsp cornstarch~~ Combine water, lemon juice, cornstarch and sugar in pot over medium heat. Stir well to dissolve cornstarch, then add fruit. Simmer for 5-10 minutes. This sauce really complements this cake. Thanks for a wonderful recipe!!! Can't wait to make it again!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good and SUPER easy with a stand mixer! I made it topped with the satiny chocolate glaze as suggested by another reviewer. Would make it again and would be good to bring to a party or potluck. I am going to try cupcakes next time. Used Duncan Hines mix.

UPDATE:
I make this cake every year for my neighbors birthday. This year, I used store brand devils food cake. It was just as good and half the price. I also accidentally bought cook and serve pudding! Oh no! I didn't realize until after I dumped in one box. I had to figure out how to save the cake. I reduced the oil to 1/2 cup, the water to 1/4 cup and only used 1 cup of mini chocolate chips. Voila! It turned out as good as normal! So if you accidentally buy the wrong pudding, no fear! Use this as your guide. I am increasing my review to 5 stars cause this is soooo easy and tastes like it took you all day. This time, I used the vanilla glaze from this site and it was great!

DELICIOUS! i accidentally added an extra cup of water and was afraid it would ruin the cake, but it was still seriously sooo goood!!!! i cut back the oil to 3/4 cup. i bake in a 9x13 or 2 9x9. it tastes even better the next day. this recipe is a keeper!! thanks for sharing the recipe :)

text:
Really great!  I used unsweetened applesauce instead of oil; egg beaters instead of eggs, fat free sour cream, sugar free pudding, and mini choc. chips.  It was really rich, so next time I will try a 1/4 less applesauce and a 1/4 less choc. chips.  This was my first time baking with the lower fat ingredients, and you really can't tell the difference.  It's def. worth saving the calories!

text:
Wow!  Best "doctored" cake mix recipe I've ever eaten.  Super moist texture and chocolaty flavor. I used a pudding-included devil's food cake mix to simplify a step.  I followed a previous reviewer's suggestion of adding mini chocolate chips for more even distribution, and I'm glad I did. Be sure you wait to dust it with powdered sugar until right before cutting and serving, or the sugar will absorb moisture and melt into the top, losing its pretty look. I served it with sliced strawberries which really made that rich chocolate flavor pop!

text:
Hmmm...I don't know what to say about this cake.  My first attempt was a total mess and never cooked through even after over an hour in the oven.  I realized that I used the smaller box of pudding mix so I tried again.  The second time I did a little research and found this exact recipe but with 1/2 c. of oil and the smaller pudding size.  This time it baked just fine but I still wasn't that impressed with the cake.  It was very heavy and dense.  Not as moist as I like even with all that extra fat.  Maybe I'm just a total cheapskate but I think that 1.25 for cake mix, 2.50 for chocolate chips, 1.00 for sour cream, 1.00 for pudding, 4 eggs, and an entire cup of oil makes for a pretty expensive recipe.  I won't be making this again.  The next time I need a good chocolate cake, I'll use "One Bowl Chocolate Cake III."  One good thing I got out of using this recipe is the suggestion by other reviewers to use "Satiny Chocolate Glaze."  That was excellent.
