text:
Without a doubt one of the best (and easiest) chocolate cake recipes ever.  I made it for the first time for DIL's birthday, using 2 nine inch pans.  I did decrease the oil by half and used light sour cream. Was concerned about how thick the batter was - think brownie mix - but gave it a go anyway.  Baked at 350 for 55 minutes.  The cake came out perfect.  Also made Creamy Chocolate Frosting recipe (doubled) from this site. Rave reviews from everyone.  My go to recipe for chocolate cake from now on.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you like chocolate cake, then you'll love this one. I used yogurt instead of sour cream. It was very very moist. Everyone at the party I took it to thought it was great.
 EDIT DEC 2011::: I've made this cake many many times now and always follow the recipe as is, but trading yogurt for sour cream. There really is no need for all the other alterations reviews mention as this cake is great as the recipe is written. Just top with your favourite topping and you're good to go!
EDIT SEPT 2014:This recipe is now my secret weapon! Using this as a base and always using yogurt in stead of sou, I've made all sorts of yummy things. I used white cake with lemon pudding and used blueberries in place of the chocolate chips, filled the layers with a blueberry reduction and topped with a light blueberry butter cream. I used white cake with pistachio pudding and chopped pistachios in place of chocolate chips and topped with a pistachio stabilized whipped cream frosting. Most recently, I used white cake with vanilla pudding, chopped fresh peaches in place of chocolate chips, and topped with a vanilla whipped cream frosting. Everyone has been begging me for the recipes!

After reading all of the 5 star reviews I was really expecting something out of this world. Well you have to be TRUE CHOCOLATE LOVER to really appreciate this cake. I followed the recipe exactly and made cup cakes. They were okay but nothing to brag about. My husband is a middle school teacher so I think I'll send the cupcakes to work with him  on tomorrow to give to his students. They might appreciate them much more than I did.

text:
Turned out as advertised--moist and so chocolaty. I followed the recipe except I used a whole pack of mini chocolate chips. I had trouble getting it done. I baked it another 10 minutes at 350, and when it still wasn't done I turned the temp down to 335 and baked another 15 minutes. Next time I'm going to try less oil and see if that takes care of it. This recipe is so delicious and easy that it's worth experimenting with to figure out the cook time.

text:
My fraternity had a bake-off this week and I was crunched for time but still wanted to make something to knock their socks off. This worked fabulously and I got so many complements on the cake! I altered it just slightly by substituting one of the cups of semi-sweet chips for chopped white chocolate chips, and for the other cup I used the suggestion of mini chips. I also made it into a layer cake which required just under 30 min to bake. Between the layers I used raspberry preserves and I topped the cake with a white chocolate glaze recipe I found on this site (originally used for cookies) and fresh raspberries. I'm eating the one little bit left over now and it is so good!

text:
This turned out nicely and came right of the bundt cake pan without problem. I planned on substituting the pudding mix with the dry ingredients from the "Hasty Chcolate Pudding" recipe on this site because I wanted to make this and had no pudding mix. I also went to put in the sour cream and my sour cream was bad, so I substituted 3/4 milk, 3/4 tbsp lemon juice (to make buttermilk) and 1/3C butter as found on substitutions list on this website. The cake still turned out great! (Next time I will have to check my ingredients better before I start)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh my! This recipe completly rocks! I added 3/4 Cup peanut butter chips and 3/4 cup chocolate chips. Also, after I greased the pan I dusted it with finely chopped pecans (this also kept it from sticking to the pan). Next I used the DELICIOUS glaze recipe (found on this site) and coated the cake with it. The glaze recipe was 1 can Sweetened Condensed Milk and 1 cup chocolate chips...melt them in the microwave then mix well, then add about a teaspoon of vanilla. While the glaze is hot pour it over the cake and allow it to set. THE BEST BUNDT CAKE EVER! Sooooo tasty and I got rave reviews!

text:
This was a fantastic recipe, and it was so easy to make!  I just bought my first bundt pan, so I needed a bundt cake recipe.  After reading the rave reviews for this cake, I decided to try it.  I'm so glad I did!  I did make some modifications though.  I only had a 3.9 oz box of pudding, so I just used that.  I also only used one cup of mini chocolate chips, fearing that it would be too rich.  I think that one cup of chocolate chips was definitely enough, as the cake was very chocolatey and rich anyway!  This got rave reviews from my co-workers and family and stayed pretty moist for several days.  I used the recipe for Satiny Chocolate Glaze from this site as a topping.  Next time I'll try making it with the larger box of pudding.

text:
I used this recipe for two layers of my wedding cake. I therefore didn't use a bunt pan, but a regular round shape.  I used a little bit less chocolate chips because I was worried they would take away from the support of the cake.  It all worked out perfectly.  I wanted to give the chocolate lovers at the wedding a real treat. They asked for chocolate and they got it.    I have also made this since the wedding as a birthday cake for a friend and roommate, and the cake remains got eaten for breakfast everyday, and everyday it got better.  I will continue making this cake for the rest of my life! I don't even want to try others.  For the icing I used a package of chocolate jello pudding mixed with regular vanilla icing (leftover Betty Crocker) and it went perfectly with this cake.

text:
DO NOT BE ALARMED by the consistency of the batter when you are ready to put it into the pan.  It is literally like sludge, and seems like it will never turn out, but it is the most moist, delicious, PERFECT chocolate cake ever!  We used the mini chocolate chips, and they were perfect as there were tiny little bits all throughout. Even though it's hard, make sure you let it cool in the pan for the full hour and a half. Also, leftover slices of this are wonderful when reheated in the microwave for about 20 seconds!

text:
I made the mistake of forgetting to tell my husband not to buy the cake mix with the pudding in it.  I used it anyways and it came out way to soft.  BUY MIX WITHOUT PUDDING.  I cut back on the oil to 1/2 cup, 1/2 cup milk, 1/2 cup of coffee and cooked it at 350 for 50 minutes.  Even though I didn't make it correct it was eaten up within 2 hours at work.  Everyone loved it.  So, it's really good even when you don't make it right.  DON'T put in the refrigerator.  If you want to put fruit in the middle of the cake don't do it until you are ready to serve.  Sprinkle with powered sugar and I used the Santiny chocolate glaze.  Remember small pieces because 600 caleries is a lot. This recipe is a keeper.

text:
I made this for my dad's 50th birthday and got rave reviews from everyone.  I didn't have enough chocolate pudding so I used one box of chocolate and one box of vanilla.  I made this in a bundt pan with the "Satiny Chocolate Glaze" and also the "Dirt Cake I" recipies. I layered the dirt cake in the hole of the bundt cake (once cooled of course) topped with a gummy worm and an over the hill grave stone candle and wrote "older than dirt" around the outside.  There was more dirt cake then could fit in the middle of the cake, so I put the rest in a tupperware container for guests to take as they pleased.  The creamy part of the dirt cake complimented the chocolate cake perfectly.  A very rich combo!

text:
My Mom started baking this cake in the 1970's.  It became her "signature" cake and of course was requested at all family gatherings.  She passed away 10 years ago, but us kids and grandkids keep the tradition going.  We called it "Inside-out Chocolate Cake".  She used 1/2 c oil and frozen chocolate chips.  The cake was unmolded after just 10 minutes, but completely cooled before dusting with powdered sugar.  Even non-chocoholics love this one and for beginner bakers this is a great recipe.

text:
Pretty good!  I did not realize I only had a smaller box of chocolate pudding mix, but this still came out good.  I made cupcakes and they were nice and moist, and as others mentioned, even better the next day.  Based on other reviews I reduced the chocolate chips to 1 cup, but frankly I think I could have done without them at all since I intended to frost the cupcakes anyway.  I used this recipe as inspiration to also make vanilla cupcakes using French vanilla cake mix and vanilla pudding (again, the smaller sized packages) and no chips.  I actually like the vanilla ones better (of course, they are slathered with chocolate frosting...).  Each batch produced 24 cupcakes, and baking time was 35 minutes for the chocolate, and 30 minutes for the vanilla.  Will make both recipes again, but if I use chocolate chips I'll just dust with powdered sugar instead of icing them.

I have made this recipe several times as a 9 x 13 cake and cupcakes.  This time when I made this recipe as cupcakes, the top edges and the bottom burned before the middle was even done.  The only thing I did different was I used regular sour cream and I usually use low fat.  This is a great recipe, but I will stick with low fat sour cream from now on.  Other reviewers have said that this doesn't even need frosting- sometimes I frost the cake/cupcakes and other times I've sprinkled powdered sugar on each piece and it still tastes great!  This is a keeper!

text:
We love this recipe.  Have made it a few times now and here's what we've learned.  It's just as good without the chocolate chips.  If you do put the chocolate chips, use the mini ones if you want them to melt fully.  The regular size chips don't melt down all the way.  It has a nice texture and is easy to frost.  We use the chocolate fudge buttercream frosting or no frosting at all!  It's a good cake just on it's own. Give it a try for an easy way to make a cake that tastes like it's "from scratch."

text:
This was so delicious and easy! I made this for Mother's Day for both my mom and mom in law. I made the following changes according to other reviewers: used about 2 cups of mini semi-sweet chocolate chips and I substituted 1/2 cup unsweetened applesauce for 1/2 the oil. The baking time took longer in my bundt pan and I turned down the temp to 325 or so near the end. It was so moist. I used powdered sugar as the recipe said. It stayed moist for days out of the refrigerator. This is a definite keeper.

city:

text:
Dense and rich chocolate cake.  It was a little oily, so next time I will cut back on the oil.  Will be making this again.  Update...I made this cake again but only used 1/2 cup oil and 1/3 cup nonfat milk and no chocolate chips (I don't like the chips in the way of the cake).  Cake was definitely not as dense but still very good, especially since it was not as oily.  I suggest cutting back on the oil and using the milk...that's how I'll be rolling with this one.  I also frosted the cake with whipped cream (so sugar added as the cake is sweet enough) and toasted chopped almonds on top...very good with the almonds (almond...buy raw in bulk from Costco and just chop and toast in a pan on low heat).

text:
I had really high hopes for this, and unfortuantely it didn't turn out the way I had thought it would.  If you are making this, make sure you do not over cook it, when you insert a toothpick in and it still has some stuck to the toothpick it is ready.  I let the toothpick come out dry and I think that is what made it not as good b/c it wasn't as moist as I thought it would be.  I hope that this helps the first time users so that they will enjoy it.

text:
Holy god, it's so good. I made it on Friday for a church picnic Sunday and it held up great, though it was tempting! I was nervous about how long it sat in the pan, as cakes cook longer in their own heat if left in the pan out of the oven, but it turned out absolutely perfect. (I used 3/4 a cup of oil, and it was a little much. If I make it again, which I was requested to do, I'll go with .5 a cup.) It was rich and moist and was eaten in all of twenty minutes!

text:
This is easy and great. It is not too sweet. I used the mini-chocolate chips which I like. I also used 1/4 C milk and 3/4 C oil. I make these as mini-bundt cup cakes (17 min.) and they are wonderful. All my friends love them. The other great thing is that they freeze really well. I froze them and just took out one or two as I wanted them and they lasted for quite a long time. The recipe made about 36 mini-bundts.

This is the best homemade chocolate cake I have ever had. I made this for a dinner party at my parents friends house that I was carted along to. The cake, and me, were praised all the way through dessert (the family are humongous chocolate fans). Because I was serving it to 6 people and I didn't feel like cutting the cake, I made the recipe like normal and baked the batter in individual small bundt cake pans. Yum, just the memory of these makes me hungry!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe for a Father's Day get together thinking that you can never have "too much" chocolate in a chocolate cake.  I fully expected to bemoan the lack of chocolate icing, but lo and behold, YOU DON'T NEED IT!  I made the recipe exactly as written (Devil's food and chocolate pudding mix, exact measurements, no low fat/sugar substitutes) except I used mini semi-sweet chocolate chips instead of regular since that's what I had on hand.   It baked for exactly fifty minutes and I dusted it with powdered sugar once it had completely cooled.  The cake was fantastically moist and the chocolate chips were soft and almost melty, even the next day!  My boyfriend summed it up nicely when he said that it tasted like the icing was INSIDE the cake, so there was no need for icing on the outside.  So good!  No one will know it wasn't made from scratch.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
The first time I made this recipe I followed it exactly. It turned out very moist, slightly crisp on the edges, and I topped it with a dusting of powder sugar. The family loved it but I thought it was a bit too much oil. I did use the mini chocolate chips and it was definitely moist to the last bite.

Taking the suggestions of other reviewers, I modified the recipe for my mother's 60th birthday. I used a Chocolate Fudge cake mix, Chocolate Mint pudding mix, 1/2 teaspoon of mint extract (probably didn't need it but chocolate mint is my mom's favorite), and Ande's mint baking chips. I used a chocolate ganache type recipe - using melted butter, 1/3 cup of cocoa powder, and 1.5 cups of confectioner's sugar- again adding 1/2 teaspoon of mint extract- the cake turned out wonderful and she loved it. I will definitely be making this recipe again and again- and experimenting with different combinations.

text:
I made this exactly as the recipe called for except that I did two round cakes for a layered cake and I used mini chips instead of regular.  It turned out really good and was very moist.  We loved it.  However, it was not nearly as moist the following day, which was disappointing.  So while we all thought this was awesome the first day, we all definitely thought it was a "day of" cake.  I frosted it with the Chocolate Frosting I and found the same results.  It was good the day I made it, but the frosting got hard the following day.  I definitely wouldn't use the frosting again, but would make the cake again.  I would just serve the cake only the day it is baked.

Just awesome. 
I just tried this recipe, I wanted to see if it would work in cake pans for a stacked cake I am making for my son's birthday, and it is fabulous. I made a couple of substitutions, milk for the water, mini chocolate chips, and I added a teaspoon of vanilla, but honestly it's awesome without that. text:
Wonderful and easy recipe!  I had to make adjustments because of what I had on hand but it still turned out tasty.  I only had cheesecake pudding on hand so I used that instead of the chocolate pudding, I had mini chocolate chips but only had one cup so I made do with that amount, the cake was moist, not overly chocolate flavored because of the cheesecake pudding and the mini chips were found throughout the bundt cake, probably because they're lighter in weight than the regular sized chips.  I used the Chocolate Ganache recipe from this website and used orange extract to flavor it, the cake disappeared in minutes.  Thank you for sharing this receipe, it's awesome!!!!

text:
In three words: good, easy, moist! I didn't have sour cream so I substituted with one cup of buttermilk, which worked just fine. (Normally you're supposed to use 3/4 c of buttermilk and 1/3 c of melted butter to substitute 1 c sour cream, but I figured there was already enough fat in this recipe.) I used 1 c of mini chocolate chips. Keep a close eye on this cake while it's baking. I checked it when I first smelled it, but it was too soon. At 50 minutes though, it had already started to burn a little. Thanks for the recipe and the helpful reviews! Good cake!

text:
This recipe is absolutely heavenly. I have made two variations now, based on another reviewer.   Very Moist and Chocolatey, without being overly sweet. My whole family loved it. I'm going to keep experiementing with this easy, delicious and versatile recipe.   Update: The original was my favorite until I experimented a little, coming up with a few personal favorites: I used white chocolate chips and put strawberry pie filling in the bundt pan before filling with cake mix. I topped the cake with rest of the strawberry filling and sifted some powdered sugar over it. Very pretty. More importantly, delicious.  Don't be afraid to play with this cake recipe. No matter what I do with it, everybody loves it. I've tried different flavored "chips", different puddings.. it all works. Next, I'm thinking of adding small caramel chunks to the cake mix and topping with dark chocolate slivers.   Like I said, endless possibilities.

Display Name:
lilpetes

2

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh my goodness!  This cake is so cool!  This is the first time I made a bunt that just plopped right out of the pan.  It might be the huge amount of oil in the cake.  Don't cut down on the oil, it's unsaturated fat.  I don't know what people are talking about with the outside getting crunchy.  I left it in the greasy pan over night to cool, and it turned out really nice, cooked perfectly.  Definitely bake it the full 55 minutes.  Some chocolate chips that were on top stuck to the bottom of the pan, but those just made a special preview of the cake for me.  Thy didn't sink, they just were on the top when I poured the batter in the pan.  The batter is too thick for the chips to sink, so don't worry about using mini-chocolate chips.  If you like or have big ones, use them.  I haven't eaten the cake yet, but the extra batter in the bowl was so good, it was like eating cookie dough, pudding, and cake batter all in one.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cake was just "okay," in my opinion...tasted pretty good, very chocolately, good consistency, but lacking a little in sweetness and flavor. Without the addition of the chocolate chips in the batter to sweeten it up and moisten the cake, it would have been thumbs down for me. Even with all of the other ingredients, it definitely had that boxed-cake flavor (which is fine if that's what you're anticipating!) in the end and not what I was expecting based on the reviews. Even so, everyone gobbled it up and it was a hit for the most part. Just a note - this cake definitely doesn't need a full cup of oil! I decided to save some fat and calories and use half of that, which is plenty - I also substituted 3/4 cup of *very* strong coffee in place of the 1/2 cup of water and it worked out well, giving a little more of a flavor dimension than water alone. Thank you for the recipe - a good base that I might try to jazz up in the future with some other more interesting ingredients. :-)

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this for a dinner we were invited to. My husband overheard the host telling someone else that this cake "was to die for." It was really moist and chocolaty.

I used a small box of pudding instead of the large, I used about 3/4 cup of oil, and I used less than half the chocolate chips it called for. The cake mix I used said it had pudding in the mix. The batter was really thick and I wasn't sure   how long to mix it. I used a whisk and stirred till everything was mixed. I had no need to worry about the batter because the cake turned out great. It reminded me of the chocolate muffins that my sister would get from a bakery.

This was really easy and quick to make. It was as easy as doing a cake mix and it didn't need frosting, just a sprinkling of powdered sugar. I would make this again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
OMG this was great! I couldn't give it 5 stars because I altered it a bit. I made cupcakes with this recipe and cooked them at 350 for 20-22 mins. I decreased the oil to 1/2c and added 1/2c milk, in addition to the 1/2 H2O. I also used low fat sour cream, and 2c. of the "mini" semi-sweet choc chips. I used a no-name brand devil's food cake mix and Jello choc pudding mix, you can really taste the pudding! It's like eating a whole pan of brownies in one cupcake! YUM... I had to laugh at the directions when it said "pour" batter into pan - there is no "pouring" of this batter, I had to spoon it out (I was doubting myself for not adding a little more oil, but it turned out great with out the extra)...It was also a little tricky to poke 'em with a toothpick cuz I kept hitting chocolate chips!
ETA: When I frist tried the cupcakes without icing, I thought it wouldn't need it. But then I used the Satiny Choc Icing (from this site) and it was PERFECT! I think I will make these as "mini" cupcakes in the future because it really is almost TOO MUCH CHOCOLATE - if there IS such a thing!

I had been waiting for an occasion to make this cake and used it for cupcakes for a baby shower.  Yum! It was as good as everyone said it was and easy also. I made no changes and it made about 30 cupcakes. I did use the mini chocolate chips which was a very good choice. Little bursts of chocolate throughout the cupcake. I followed the suggestion of another reviewer and tried it with a french vanilla cake and french vanilla pudding. On this one I didn't add any chips. It was delicious also. The only change I added to that version was to add extra vanilla, just due to personal preference. I highly recommend this recipe and will use again with other variations.

The only change I made was to add a handful of fresh pitted cherries as it is cherry season here. Yummm.

text:
i received this recipe from a friend. her instructions said to grease and flour the bundt pan. after you take it out of over to immediately cover with a plate and invert on to plate...then cover with plastic wrap and put in frig.  when you remove it all of the moisture stays in the cake.  the most moist cake i have ever eaten...oh take of plastic wrap and leave uncovered for short while.  just before serving sprinkle with powdered sugar.  mmmmm

userID:
15942024
Display Name:
LoriAnn
isPro:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making this cake for years with slight changes only.  I reduce the oil to 3/4 cup and add 1 tablespoon of vanilla extract.  The baking is where it got tricky, but with experimentation it comes out perfect every time.  Definitely use a well-greased bundt pan since it so dense it may not cook right otherwise.  I preheat the oven to 350 degrees, but ONLY bake it at that temperature for 30 minutes, reducing heat to 300 degrees and cooking 45 minutes more or until top is springy to the touch and a wooden skewer/toothpick inserted comes out clean.  Yes, it does need to cool for at least an hour and a half before inverting onto a plate.  Chilling it overnight is where I veer away from your typical chocolate cake.  My family feels it is best cold since the chips harden up a little again and makes it a unique treat!  I LOVE chocolate and eat frosting with a spoon, but just a sprinkle with powdered sugar is plenty and a pretty finish.

text:
This is my go-to recipe and I use it any time I make a cake that I want to impress everyone with.  Here's a tip- sometimes I use a bit less oil or sour cream, or whichever liquid because my cake was caving in slightly on the sides. Just the slightest bit less and my cake came out perfectly. I also never add chocolate chips.  I'm not a fan of too-chocolatey.
Denise. You're a genius.

text:
It is not fair for me to rate this recipe as I don't love chocolate.  However, I do enjoy eating the frosted crumbs after this cake has been devoured by my family and friends.  First time, I made it as written.  The eaters of the cake LOVED IT!  Later,  I made just a few adjustments.  Subbed the 1/2 cup water with coffee.  Added 1/3 cup flour because I'm at high altitude.  Makes the cake stay risen. I'm have a cake business and this is the only recipe I use now. Rave reviews from all to whom I serve this cake.

I following the recipe for the quantities but used sugar free pudding mix instead of the high sugar type.I used a bit more than one cup of chocolate ships ( Ghirardelli bitter sweet) instead of two full cups. I also added instant coffee to the water but I don't think it affected the flavor at all. I dusted the cake with powdered sugar cause I thought it would be enough chocolate without any glaze or frosting. I will definitely make this again. I baked it at 335 degrees and kept testing it. I live at over 7,200' elevation, so baking has to be adjusted for most things.

Hubby is not a chocoholic nor is he a fan of cake, but kept nibbling at this cake all evening! As with others, I compensated for the size of cake mix and pudding mix by decreasing all liquids and only using 3 eggs. I will be using this recipe again, maybe with other flavours of cake mixes, puddings and chips!

text:
The recipe calls for a cake mix that is 18.25 ounce. It never crossed my mind to check the weight.   I followed the suggestions and added 1/3 cup of milk but knew I couldn't add the water. That's when I checked to see why my mixture was wet enough. The box was 15.25 ozs. I added some mix from another cake I was making to get the right consistency. I made a cupcake 1st to taste and it needed something. I added moose in the middle and melted can frosting to pour on top. It tasted good and got great reviews from the family. The mini chips didn't melt, but folks liked the crunch. Please adapt this recipe for the new 15.25 oz box size.

I only didn’t give this 5 stars because I didn’t make it accurately. It wasn’t until I was making it that I realized my box of cake mix and pudding were smaller than the recipe requires. I thought I had just the standard size. I adjusted the additional ingredients to what I thought was appropriate for the lesser mix. I also attempted to adjust the cooking time for cupcakes instead of bundt cake... that sank a lot as soon as they cooled. So needless to say it was a failed execution. Regardless, it was so so tasty! We made our own frosting recipe as well, but it was incredible, and made up for the sinking cake!

country:
None
text:
This is fabulous. 
It is a huge hit every time I serve it anywhere. It is also very versatile.  The only thing I change for the chocolate version is that I use espresso or Khahlua instead of water. It really deepens the chocolate flavor. I always top it with a chocolate ganache, and it is too yummy for words. 
I've also made different versions of it with other flavors of cake mix, like using lemon cake mix, adding homemade limoncello as the liquid and adding vanilla baking chips. I've used a butter pecan cake mix and added butterscotch chips, and replaced a tablespoon of the liquid with a good vanilla extract. It turned out very nicely. 
It's hard to beat a recipe that's this good and can be changed up to give so much variety. It's my go-to cake recipe now!

userID:
12653008
Display Name:
bee
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Like a lot of other reviewers, I initially shied away from this recipe because of the box mix. But, I wanted something somewhat hassle free for a party and couldn’t deny all the great reviews, so I gave it a shot. Like some, I used a fudge cake mix instead of the angel food, but still used the chocolate pudding and a cup of mini chocolate chips. (Also cut the oil in half for a 1/2 c oil and 1/2 cup applesauce.) The cake rose beautifully and resulted in thick, dense, but also moist, cakes. I used a chocolate buttercream and raspberry preserve combo to sandwich between the two before frosting it with the rest of the chocolate butter cream, and these were a great compliment to the cake. Truly enjoyed all the flavors and textures together (definitely recommend the mini chocolate chips, but I’ll probably add 1.5-2 cups next time.) I also think next time that I’ll cut the cakes in half to create 4 layers and use the raspberry/buttercream to stack between, as it would lighten up this heavy cake some. Giving this a 4 instead of 5 because, like some reviewers pointed out, it IS a jazzed up box cake recipe (although a great one!) but I thought the flavors would be a little more explosive, given the reviews. But I’ll be making this again and also love it’s versatility. Definitely recommend!

Someone asked me to make a cake so I just looked up chocolate cake on here (everyone always loves chocolate cake right?) and this was the first recipe I saw. I was planning on making a round cake but didn’t realize I didn’t own cake pans until I had already bought all the ingredients for a buttercream frosting, so I had to frost the bundt cake, which turned out ok. text:
I used mini chips , one cup, ad 1/2 cup coffee in place of water.  I would use large chips ...I . think you'd get more of a " surprise" chocolate  .  I did use large muffin tins, turned them upside down to frost with satiny glaze.  They are much better at least one day later....they are too cake-like for my preference  with same day serving.  

The glaze was a negative..I ended up making it twice, liked the suggestio of taking the butter, syrup off the heat to add the chocolate....a much smoother presentation.  I saw the suggstion of Ghirardelli bits too late.  I would also use them for a richer texture and flavor.

text:
This should be renamed "Never Too Much Chocolate" cake.  Easy to make, and got rave reviews from family and friends.  It's a very rich, dense, moist, deliciously chocolate cake.  Followed the recipe exactly.  Convection baked it in a stoneware  bundt pan.  Definately let it cool the full 1.5hrs.  Dusted it with confectioners sugar using a sifter.  I chose to put in the refrigerator, and served it cold/chilled.  This recipe is a keeper!

text:
Not my favorite chocolate cake recipe (unaltered version), but pretty good! For those who have asked in other reviews, I have tried this as a bundt cake and as cupcakes. It is much better as a bundt cake! It dries out very badly as cupcakes and loses much of that rich flavor. I made these cupcakes with peanut butter frosting and you could barely taste ANY chocolate flavor. In a pinch, I may use this recipe again (for last-minute bundt cake needs), but I also have other chocolate cake recipes that seem to be enjoyed more by my family and friends!

text:
I traditionally follow a recipe as written the first time around and then adjust to my family’s taste. But in this case, I simply wanted to bake a cake and clean out my pantry. (#shelftember) I used a German chocolate cake mix, a box of Oreo pudding mix, 1/2 cup of sour cream (it was all that I had in my fridge), 1/2 cup unsweetened applesauce, 3/4 cup of oil (per others suggestion), 1/2 cup of coffee, 4 eggs, and some leftover Heath toffee bits and holiday chocolate chips. Again, forgive me, but I was simply trying to utilize what I had laying around but there’s no denying the results were fantastic! I didn’t change the ingredients enough that I think this is a poor review. It shows that this is a simple and flexible recipe that can be easily adjusted. I’m imagining toffee chips or mint chips instead of chocolate chips, folding in chopped cherries and using grenadine instead of water, yellow cake mix with vanilla pudding and white chips for my chocolate hating father, the possibilities are endless. Bon Appetit!

Display Name:
Eri Hoshina

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3114006.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Definitely a wonderful chocolate cake and I am definitely making it again!

But I will use smaller chocolate chips next time following the suggestions of some of the reviewers. Because the chocolate chips sink at the bottom while baking, the top of the cake (after inverted for serving) gets all the chocolate chips. So most of the richness is there. This creates decadent experience there, but the bottom part tastes dry and boring. 


For me, ganache is a must for this cake. I made ganache with 2 cup of heavy milk just heated enough to start boiling dumped on to 2 cup of chocolate chips following one of the recipes from here, but this came too watery to pour on the cake to stick on the surface, and I needed to add quite a bit of chocolate chips before actually using. This measurement gives you a lot of ganache. If you are making it just for the cake, you can probably make enough with 1/2 heavy milk and 3/4 chocolate chips, plus 1/4 teaspoon vanilla extract.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2018-07-26T20:51:41.113
helpfulCount:
0

text:
Delicious! Perfecto! Used lowfat vanilla greek yogurt instead of  sour cream, 1/2 applesauce  1/2 oil,,  3 eggs, 1/4c coffee, 1 cup mini choc chips.  Baked in 2 - 9" round pans at 330 for 40 minutes.  Frosted with ganache (1 cup heavy cream brought to boil, pour over 3/4 bag ghiradelli bittersweet chips - whisk), some ganache and some whipped cream between layers . Refrigerate. Really the best cake ever.

text:
I made it as a double layer cake and frosted it with a light vanilla frosting. I don’t have a bundt pan so I halved it into two 9” pans and baked it for 30 mins. It turned out flat on top and baked perfectly! It’s dense and almost brownie like, the only thing I’d point out is that once placing them on top the weight slightly affected the the bottom layer but nothing too great. My 3 boys really liked it and said it went perfectly with a glass of milk. I agree. :)

country:
None
text:
Great cake!
After noticing my pudding box was 3.9oz and not as the recipes calls (5.9oz), I also halved the oil to 1/2 cp. In lieu of the water, I used 1/2 cp. whole milk. In lieu of the sour cream, I used same amount of whole milk yougurt and it turned out great. 
I completely omitted the extra chocolate chips and made a loose golden graham cereal/marshmallow mix for between the two layers.
The two 9" rounds cooked for about 35 minutes at 330.

This cake is delicious! I made it using 5.9 oz of Godiva chocolate pudding mix, and 1 c of Ghiradelli semi sweet chocolate chips. As others suggested I only added 1/2 c of oil and added 1/3 c of milk along with the warm water. It had a slight crisp outside and the inside was deliciously gooey while the cake was still a bit warm. Hopefully when it cools it will still stay gooey inside.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/403232.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVE this cake.  I make most cakes from scratch but this is a  keeper!  I have tried adjusting (that's just me) but  this original is the way to go.  I like the regular size choc. chips as I end up with little luscious bits in the cake.  My advice?  Make as directed and don't over-complicate. That after all is the reason for using a mix.  I just spray my pan, mix everything together and bake.   I only use pwd sugar for the frosting as I really want the cake to shine.   I do believe the difference in a very good cake and an awesome one is the baking time.  Don't overbake!  You want the moist, gooey, cake and a few minutes over will still be good but not as delicious.  Thanks Denise!

text:
Made just as is but with mini chocolate chips, and as a double layer cake with straight up chocolate frosting, and it is the best cake ever.  The mini chips melted into the cake while baking, resulting in a rich chocolaty cake. The cake is even better on the second day, which makes this cake perfect for making ahead. The texture became more moist and rich,  and denser overnight.  Day 3 -- snuck a slice for breakfast before my kids woke up :-) Just as good and so good with coffee, ya know!

text:
This was an amazing cake! So simple and so delicious. It seems fool proof. I followed the recipe as is, and baked at 350 for 55 minutes. The cake came out perfect in that time. I couldn’t wait and hour and a half for it to cool before dumping it, and it still turned out beautiful. However, it is difficult to add sprinkled sugar on it when it is warm. The sugar melts and does not give the dusted effect as easily. Otherwise amazing, and I was short on time. Excellent cake.

country:
None
text:
This thing is a huge success every time I make it! We eat gluten free, and even when this is made our way, gluten-eaters still love it! To make this gluten free, simply use a gluten-free cake mix. Pamela’s brand is good, and if your store has the special gf recipe, Betty Crocker is good, too. We use Jello brand pudding, and we always check the bag of chocolate chips to make sure they are gluten free. Nestle has worked for us, and a couple of other brands. To be safest, you can get these in the organic section where they are clearly marked. Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
Best and easiest chocolate cake recipe ever!  I used a convection oven and tested out 325F at 49 min, which caused crispy edges but the cake was delicious and moist.  Next attempt (with new oven) I plan to decrease temp on convection bake to 320 or 315 and cook longer.  So many compliments!  I am tempted to try the other options of cake mix and pudding, but this original is so amazing why bother.

text:
I combined 2 recipes i saw. This was the main recipe but i made it gluten free and added cherry pie filling. The gf cake mix wasn't quite 18.25 oz so i added a cup of gf bisquick mix and I didn't have sour cream so i made sour milk and added melted butter. I wasn't sure how it would turn out with the can of pie filling but it was delicious and moist! I added 2tsp of almond extract which added a nice background flavour. I only added one cup of chocolate chips because i thought it might be too sweet but it's not overly sweet. I think i would add more cherry filling but i think i would drain some of the sauce and just add more of the fruit. And possibly more almond extract.

text:
This recipe was absolutely delicious! The BF thought it was the best cake he had ever tasted. 
I did make some slight adjustments. 
The recipe calls for 1c of oil, thats a lot of oil! I switched the veg oil up and replaced with 1/2c of melted coconut oil and used a pudding pack for the other half of the liquid. I also used a skim milk sour cream. Delish and much healthier! :)

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4143322.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I usually make everything from scratch, including chocolate cake. I buy expensive cocoa and chips to make sure it meets my family's chocolate requirements. But This easy box cake was amazing and I'm not going back to my old recipe again. I followed this recipe exactly except I followed other reviewers recommendations. I only put in 1 cup chocolate chips, 1/2 cup oil, 1/3 cup heavy cream (didn't have milk), and put in espresso powder with the warm water to bring out the chocolate flavor. I also only had the instant 3.4 oz pudding mix, but it still tasted fine. I cooked this in a 13 X 9 pan for about 45 minutes and it was divine!!! Didn't need To frost this, so good!! I will try the original recipe that calls for all oil and no dairy, but for this time around adding the dairy gave it a good crumb and it wasn't crispy on the outside.

userID:
3259044
Display Name:
Ritalovestocook
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
123
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh my goodness, this is the best cake I have ever made. I live in a very high altitude (7500') area and bundt cakes are the only cakes I can make that don't implode. I have been searching for years for a recipe made with a box mix that I can change up. Last nite using this recipe, I made an orange cake, I hesitated a minute on the full cup of oil, then I read another review and she commented that it WAS a cake. So on I went the heck with the fat and calories!  I substituted 1/2 c. of juice from canned mandarin oranges for the water plus added 2 T. flour for high altitudes. 
I always use the container frosting, but I have to make it my own. I used vanilla frosting added butter, a few drops of orange extract and 2 T of juice from mandarin oranges. I added powdered sugar and beat it to the right consistency. I had put about 3/4 c. of mandarin oranges on a paper towel to drain, then chopped them and folded them into the frosting. 
When the cake was done, I waited 1 1/2 - 2 hours before I flipped it. (Per recipe). I didn't taste it till this morning, this cake is WONDERFUL!!  I will definitely make the chocolate and a family favorite; cherry chip and on and on and on. To the person who submitted this recipe a great big THANK YOU I have finally found the bundt cake recipe that I've been searching for!!!!!!
Be sure to note the recipe calls for the LARGE box of instant pudding not the usual small box.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6461518.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm in love with this concept. The taste was beyond delicious. I frosted it with a very thick, dark ganache. Most of my choco chips sank to the bottom of the pan, even after I covered them generously with flour, and that's because my batter came out a little too watery, even though I added only half the quantity of water suggested in  the recipe. I don't blame the original poster for it, though. I'm the one who must compensate for the local altitude/humidity. I'll cut the chips smaller next time, and experiment with the oil/water and wet/dry ingredients ratio.

text:
I got this recipe, with a few changes, from a relative and an Air Force wife friend more than 30 years ago!  I added 1 tsp. of vanilla, and 1  T. of instant coffee. ( Coffee intensifies the chocolate flavor!) I also use only 6 oz. of the chips in the cake and use the other 6 ox to make a choc. glaze. Melt the chips, 2 T of light corn syrup, and 1 tsp. H2O. Use to glaze the cake!  YUM!

text:
So delicious, especially warmed a bit due to the chocolate chips inside. Used Nestle Toll House semi-sweet chips. Could make a strawberry or cherry glaze but think the chocolate glaze makes it too rich. I used powdered sugar. Could not find the cake mix recommended so used Duncan Hines Swiss Chocolate and it was fantastic! Took exactly 50 minutes. Cooled 1 1/2 hrs in pan before inverting. Just sprayed inside bundt pan with PAM only. I would highly recommend this moist, chocolate cake.

text:
I have to admit, I tend to shy away from any boxed cake mix. However, I plunged ahead with this one, and I'm glad I did. The addition of sour cream and chocolate chips helped in "masking the box-y" cake flavor. I used this recipe as a base for a layered cake. I followed the directions, but I made this into 2 layers. I made a generous batch of chocolate ganache to use as a "filling" between the layers, and I made my own berry whipped cream to spread over the top. Dusted with black cocoa powder and it was stunning! I let it sit in the fridge over night to help develop the flavors. Will keep this in my personal favorite folder :)

None
text:
Super moist, rich flavor (but not overly so).  

Subbed applesauce for veg oil, used mini chocolate chips instead of semisweet morsels.  The mini chips spread throughout the whole batter, instead of semisw chips sinking to bottom of bundt pan.  

Added 2T of coffee granules to the batter - adds another layer of earthy richness to the cake.  

Did I mention it's extremely moist?  mmm  hmm...

text:
This cake is a chocolate lover's dream. I only used 3/4 cup of sour cream, and 1/2 cup mini semi-sweet chocolate chips. I also added another 1/4 cup of water, and used white instead of brown eggs. I used a rectangular cake pan, and baked about 50 minutes. I let it cool for an hour, and then cut in half to make 2 cakes. I frosted with Hershey Chocolate fudge frosting. The most delicious cake ever!!

text:
I made the recipe just as is and it turned out dense and moist and wonderful. I did cupcakes, and the recipe made 24 heaping beauties. And baked for 20 minutes. When they first came out the tops were like brownie crust. But after over night in an airtight container they were soft. Both ways were delicious. I was told they were my best cupcakes ever and that they were like the fillet mignon of cupcakes.  I topped them with the Chocolate Fudge buttercream Frosting recipe (made with all butter and no shortening), also from this site,  which is hands down the best there is.. 
Thank you for such a great treat!

userID:
2282601
Display Name:
Haven

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
According to the recipe it calls for a boxed cake mix roughly 18.25 oz. - I could not find a single company that makes one that size, so used the only option 15.25 oz. size box ( I bought one Pillsbury Moist Supreme devils food and one Betty Crocker super moist devils' food), as I made a double recipe.  I wonder as there is less mix in these smaller boxes of cake mix, should one increase the flour or something else in the recipe?  I don't know, if anyone has any idea please post it.  I didn't, but not sure if it would help.  

I actually made this into cupcakes, and the baking time ended up being a lot longer (than what it stated on the box for cooking time), roughly 28 minutes on 350 degrees.  I used paper baking cups in the muffin pan, and noticed once taking them out the tray was loaded in grease, and the paper baking cups were soaked in oil (after baking), had to put them on a paper towel to absorb the oil.

I think this recipe works best as a cake rather than cupcakes, but if you do it with cupcakes, remember to change the cooking time (its NOT what it says on the box, as they would be raw), needed roughly 28-30 minutes.  Also if doing as cupcakes, I would decrease the amount of oil used - not sure by how much less, but definitely a lot less, I would try 1/2 the oil quantity in the recipe.  

Otherwise they came out nice.  Made a buttercream frosting to use on top of these.

Made quite a few cupcakes - forgot how many but roughly 40+ with a double recipe.

text:
Made this Monday night (3/28/2016) for my daughter's 13th birthday. 
Per reading some comments here, I opted to add only a few milk chocolate chips on top, less to sink & burn at the bottom, instead of the 2 cups suggested. 
Only used 3/4 cup sour cream. 
Also folded 2-4 tablespoons of caramel sundae topping to the batter, before scooping into the greased, flowered prepared pans. 
& used 1 - 9 inch pan, 1 - 8 inch pan & 1 - 3.5 inch pan! 
Something different. She loved it! 
Baked it 35 minutes on 350, checked it, not done, turned heat down to 300 for last 15 miutes, checked every 5 min until done. (Didn't want it dried out.) 
The cake was fabulous!! Talk about delicious!! ????Moist! Scrumptious! YUMMY! 
Maybe add some 'Lindt Lindor Milk Chocolate' pieces chopped up or 'Milk Duds' chopped up (so they melt).

Made homemade chocolate butter cream frosting (that didn't turn out so well, 1st time tried it.) Maybe if  I'd attempted it different recipe or used ingredients, results would have been more successful, but I used what I had on hand. {Word to the wise: Don't use Almond extract, [or if you do, use 1/4 - 1/2 tsp. not 1 tsp., amplifies the "CHOCOLATE" taste] to make chocolate butter cream frosting, & use less coacoa powder (1/4 cup), than calls for.]
But, this will be my new main go-to cake to make. 
The butter cream frosting, will not be chocolate, or if so, made with vanilla. Will keep you posted. ?

text:
Fantastic cake! I goofed and bought a 15.9 oz triple chocolate cake mix instead of an 18 oz box of devils food cake. So I had to adjust a little. Used 3/4 c light sour cream, 1/2 c oil, and added 1/2 c skim milk because my batter was too thick. But it still came out great! Topped with a chocolate glaze recipe posted on this site, some mini chocolate chips & Heath topping. Tasted even better after sitting in the frig a day. Will definitely make again. Best chocolate cake ever!

text:
I was given this recipe years ago when a friend brought to an event the absolute best cake I have ever had! The only difference is that it was a chocolate run cake!! Instead of the water and 1 cup of oil, use 1/2 cup of oil, 1/2 cup of Myres Dark Rum and 1/2 cup of cooled brewed coffee. I also only use 2 eggs. I serve it without icing so as not take away from the other great flavors. It is best served warm, but still incredible cold! For the record, when I first had the cake, it was served with a warm cherry sauce on top, but I like it plain!!

text:
This was a delicious cake! I chose to put melted chocolate chips on top of the cake instead of adding them into the mixture as indicated in the recipe. I felt like this gave an attractive appearance while maintaining the perfect amount of chocolate flavor. If you're looking for a tasty and easy chocolate cake recipe, give this a try. It's definitely rich and full of chocolate goodness. The Devils food cake mix component of this recipe makes it easy and quick to prepare. It pays to be patient and let your cake cool a couple hours before removing from the baking pan. Waiting for the cake to cool was the most difficult part of this recipe. It looked and smelled so good I wanted to try a slice right out of the oven!

country:

text:
This cake was exceptional.  I followed the directions exactly as written (except I used the "mini" chocolate chips) and it came out very moist and delicious.  I preheated my oven about 20 minutes to make sure it was the right temperature and then baked the cake for 50 minutes without opening the oven door.  It turned out perfectly level.  However, I did notice the outer edge of the cake and a thin ring around the center hole of the bundt pan cooked a little more than the rest but not bad.  I wonder if next time I should reduce the heat a bit maybe the last 15 minutes of bake time.  Either way, this cake is so moist and delicious, you will be glad you made it.  For a glaze, I followed others recommendations and made the "Satiny Chocolate Glaze" from this site.  It was delicious on this cake.  Both recipes are definitely keepers.

text:
I made this cake today. I had a devil's food cake box that was getting old and didn't want to toss it. I took some advise from several other reviews. Lowered the oil to 3/4cup, used 1cup mini chips and used coffee instead of water and added a splash of vanilla. Used a bundt pan and baked at about 340 for 55min...turned out wonderful! Best success I've had with a new recipe in a while. We've been nibbling on it plain and it's great but I think I'll go try the glaze the reviews mentioned...definitely a keeper...oh, I used a small box of the pudding

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe for the most part.  I've done it as called for using mini chocolate chips so they don't sink to the bottom, and I've also done the same thing with a yellow cake mix and vanilla pudding.  The only thing I don't like about it is that it seems to be limited as to what shape/size of cake you make.  I've done the bundt cake & that's great, I've done a standard 9" round cake, and that comes out fine.  I've tried to do larger cakes, and this cake is so heavy and the chocolate chips impact the ability of the cake to hold together that it falls apart.  I make larger cakes for various reasons, and I would love to use this recipe for those because it is so yummy and moist, but I haven't had success so far.  If I had, I would have given this 5 stars.

My family and I loved this recipe.  I added a chocolate glaze to it and it was absolutely delicious. 

For the glaze:
1  3.5oz dark chocolate bar (I like 70%)
1/4 cup of melted butter
3-4 tablespoons of light corn syrup depending on how thick you want your glaze to be

text:
These were amazing!  I wanted cupcakes, which ended up baking at 350 for 19 minutes.  I got 30 of the most moist and delicious cupcakes I have ever eaten.  Be aware that they don't rise quite as much as normal cupcakes, so you really need to fill the muffin tins 3/4 full of batter.  Also, I swapped out mini chocolate chips for the regular sized ones (as I thought that size suited cupcakes better), and it worked perfectly!

country:
None
text:
This is an amazing cake and very easy. I suggest ignoring the reviews that say to reduce the oil. I made this both ways and it is so much more moist and delicious with the full amount! I understand the desire to avoid the oil for health reasons but it's a chocolate cake...it's really not going to be too healthy no matter how you slice it so you might as well get the full effect! In my opinion, you're really missing out on a great cake when you skimp on the oil because it seemed to change the texture significantly. This is a great recipe; will definitely be bringing this to family holiday dinners in the future. Didn't even need frosting!

Guests loved this cake! The only advice I would offer is when using the stick technique to see if it is cooked, keep in mind there are chocolate chips in the recipe. I used the technique a few times and the stick would come out coated in chocolate, I almost burnt the cake thinking in needed more time! I am also a beginner to baking though.. so for any other beginners..words of wisdom!

I made it in a 9x13 baking pan and substituted unsweetened applesauce for the oil, fat- free sour cream & sugar-free pudding as other reviewers suggested. It was OMG Delicious! My family is more of a pie- eating bunch since cakes can be dry, but we were a cake-eating crew with this one! This cake is so moist and delicious that you can eat it without frosting. The eyes close with every bite - even with the substitutions!

text:
I love this cake! We have out of state friends visiting and I wanted to make a desert quickly so I could join everyone outside. The cake did not take long to put together and is delicious. One change I made, was using 1 cup of Greek Yogurt in place of sour cream. I use Greek Yogurt as a substitute for sour cream often and it has always worked well for me. I also did not use the Glaze Icing on the cake but used powdered sugar instead. The cake was still a bit warm when I served it, so I added a scoop of ice cream. Everyone enjoyed the cake and my friend is now interested in checking out allrecipies. com!

None
text:
Wonderful, very moist cake!  My 3 yr. old was wanting to make a chocolate cake.  I had most of the ingredients on hand and had to substitute a few I didn't have or had little of.  I had to sub 1 cup greek yogurt for the sour cream, only had 1/2 c. choc. chips, and 1/2 c. eevoo (I added a tsp. of dark cocoa powder to mask any flavor from this oil). Even with the substitutions this recipe came out great.  Would make a great plain choc. cake as well, but I will definitely make again with all the chocolate chips next time (I love chocolate).  We ended up using a 9x13 pan as I don't have a bunt pan, and baked it for 325 in convection oven for 35-40 min.  Then we topped it with peanut butter frosting and mini m&ms (my sons touch).  Cannot wait to play around and try different flavors with this recipe.  Thanks!

text:
Wow! Is this decadent! I first made this for my 10-year-old granddaughter's birthday. She's a chocoholic, but I'm slowly converting her to other flavors. I made it as the recipe prescribed at first, but have since experimented by subbing greek yogurt for the sour cream and later Fit & Lively yogurt instead of greek yogurt, skim milk for the water, decreasing the oil and subbing an equal amount of skim milk, adding raisins, etc... It freezes well, and Hubby and I enjoy a thin slice topped by fudge tracks icecream in the evening. Yummmmmmy. Try the idea behind this cake to a box of brownies - GREAT!

text:
Exactly what it sounds like. This is a super chocolatey cake, just a winner all around. I made up a simple glaze for it but I'm sure this would be great with or without. I did use about half the amount of chocolate chips and it was plenty. Maybe mini chips would be nice little flecks throughout the batter but regular sized ones were too big to use the full amount called for, imho. Definitely keeping this on file for those crazy days only chocolate can fix! ;) Very quick to mix up, too!

text:
I made this for extended family at our annual Christmas gift exchange in early December.  I followed the recipe exactly and the chocolate lovers said I could make it every year from now on......LOL  My aunt asked for the recipe and took it to the monthly senior's luncheon at church the next week and it received rave reviews there also.  Thank you for a very moist chocolate bundt cake recipe.

UPDATE - took this cake to family reunion last Sunday........disappeared!  This time I used the mini morsels and I liked the texture of the cake much better......just lightly sifted powdered sugar over the top and it was so yummy I had a piece myself and I can usually resist chocolate cake.

12 month UPDATE - I have made this cake at least 4 times this year.  Everyone loves it because it is super moist....2 months ago I had 5 slices left after a summer potluck.  I put them in a bag, stuck them in in the freezer and then forgot about them until my husband was asking about dessert one night.  I took them out, let them defrost for about 30 minutes, zapped in the microwave for 15 seconds and they were warm, gooey and just as wonderful as they were when first made.  I think I will try a different version for my aunt's Christmas party this year.

text:
Wonderful! If you don't have sour cream, you can sub plain Greek yogurt and it works great. I was worried this wouldn't have time to cool and would either crumble to pieces or stick to the pan's edges when turned over - I was baking it for a party and had less than an hour after taking it from the oven to let it cool before needing to leave. But, I generously greased my pan, generously dusted with powdered cocoa and put the cake in the fridge after baking to cool faster. When it was time to turn it over, the pan was still warm and I was nervous but, the cake slid out beautifully. Very moist and rich!

text:
With all the five star ratings, I had high expectations when I made this for my dad's birthday.  It's nowhere near as moist as a typical wacky cake or one-bowl chocolate cake from scratch recipe. There were lots of unfinished pieces of cake, including mine and I ALWAYS finish my cake! No one asked to take home a piece, and I dumped the leftovers in the compost next morning.  Too bad because it was actually more effort than my usual from scratch recipe since I had to go out and buy cake and pudding mixes rather than using basic staple ingredients.  It's back to scratch for me!

text:
I followed the recipe exact, except that I only had 3.9 oz. chocolate pudding box, so I used 1 1/2 boxes more or less....
and I used 1 package of 12 oz. Nestle mini semi-sweet chocolate chips. It measured out to 2 cups. I baked in a regular round cake pan and made cupcakes. These were chocolatey and moist! they tasted ok.



*Update*
I made this again a few days ago and used Super Moist Triple Chocolate Fudge cake mix by Betty Crocker. This cake mix already had mini mini chocolate chips and used 3.9 oz. pudding mix.
I lightly frosted it with chocolate frosting and then put crumbled cake on top and a cherry pie filling/topping  on top.
They were so moist and delicious!!!!!

text:
This one is definitely a "bake and take" for the Church or Office lunch. Really easy to put together. Turns out the oven here is a bit fast so the cake came out a touch drier than I would have preferred; used the correct baking time. I'll ratchet back the oven time a little bit and see if that improves things. By the way, using the mini-chocolate pieces makes great sense. Didn't have any problems with the amount of oil and the cake fell out of the bundt pan after it was cooled completely. Enjoy.

text:
Decided to go with this recipe for my Mom's b-day cake based on all the positive reviews, and it was a complete hit!  I was concerned it was going to be too chocolatey or 'cheap' given it wasn't from scratch but thought so many positive reviews couldn't be wrong.... I used 3/4 cup of oil, low fat sour cream and cut up 1 1/2 cups of chocolate that my Mom loves instead of using chocolate chips and it was fantastic. Next time I might use 1/2 cup of oil but not a big change I'm sure.  Given the name my company were all a little concerned it was going to be too sweet and only took a small slice but everyone said it wasn't and was actually one of if not the best chocolate cakes they've had and asked for seconds. :) I topped it with my friend's Mother's fluffy chocolate butter icing and provided a choice of whipped cream or ice cream. :)

text:
this will be the second time I make this cake. I made it last time and thought I messed it up. I used vanilla pudding and added some cocoa. i added half cup flour to offset the extra moisture. Everything else I did according to the recipe except I took it out fifteen minutes early because I thought it was burning. It was one of the best cakes I ever had. And I had a lot of cake. this time I don't have a full cup of vegetable oil so I used the rest of my butter melted and used apple sauce to top it off. I have used all separately but never together. My guess is it will work fabulously. It better it is my birthday cake and it's ten o'clock at night. I am gonna top it off with a chocolate ganache this time.

text:
This was amazing, and it didn't need frosting.  I was worried about the rich batter rising correctly because my elevation is 6100 ft so I made the following high altitude adjustments: add 1/4 cup flour to dry ingredients and 1/4 cup water to the wet ingredients when mixing.  Made with high altitude adjustments and baked in a bundt pan, cooking time was 50 to 55 minutes at 340 degrees.

text:
I made this for Christmas dinner dessert. I followed the recipe exactly. I sprinkled powered sugar on top. It has a good taste, but it's really oily. Next time, I think I'll substitute some unsweetened applesauce for at least half of the oil. I also think I will use a cream cheese frosting of some type. 
I was worried about it deflating from over mixing (based on comments), but I watched the video and followed it using my KitchenAid mixer. I let it cool completely. No deflating at all.

text:
You can never have too much chocolate! Baked this today (for my bday) in two 8" rounds and it came out PERFECT! 35-40ish min at 350 did the trick. I cut the oil in 1/2 as other reviewers suggested, next time I will use 3/4 cup. I also used Ghiradelli mini chips, which was excellent and distributed evenly throughout the batter, and frosted with a buttercream I added just a little cocoa powder to. My kids said "BEST CAKE EVER"!

text:
I have used this recipe for years - it is a very good cake as is, but I have found that reducing the oil to 3/4 cup is much better, especially if making cupcakes.   It is just too heavy and "wet" when using the full cup.   I also use this recipe as a base for other flavors - I leave out the chocolate chips and use any combination of cake mix and pudding for a variety of flavors.  It is definitely my "go-to" recipe for cupcakes.

text:
Well, I may be in the minority here, but I wasn't impressed. I made this recipe twice, following the directions exactly each time and both times the cake, while not bad, tasted like a cake mix cake. I even tried different brands of cake mix and pudding mix-no change. Neither cake tasted especially rich, moist or chocolately. They were just ok-not bad tasting and adding chocolate chips to anything always helps. But I expected something much richer given the name. I will, however, fully vouch for the Satiny Chocolate Glaze from this site, which I used to top both cakes. Definitely not a traditional frosting, so don't expect something creamy, but a perfectly smooth, rich chocolate topping that is somewhere between a syrup and a full on frosting.

text:
Excellent! Moist and flavorful, exactly what you want in a cake. The only complaint I have is the oiliness-- I make cupcakes more than cakes and so the oil completely soaked through the cupcake liners (even if I double lined them!). When I make the cake, I'll use the regular amount of oil, but if I make cupcakes, I'll try 3/4 cup to keep the greasiness down. I'll never use another chocolate cake recipe ever again!

text:
I gave this a whirl yesterday. I followed the ingredient list almost to a tee except I had only bought one container of the pudding mix so I had about 25% of what the recipe calls for. That turned out to be a blessing in disguise since this cake is one heavy, rich mutha. My only other comment might have something to do with high altitude baking; I did add a few tbsp. of flour (because of our altitude) and I baked the cake for a full 55 minutes. It could have probably used maybe five additional minutes. All in all, this one's a keeper.

text:
This cake was EXCELLENT! and I can make it NON DAIRY!! I was looking for a new chocolate cake recipe to try, and I found this one. I was skeptical at first because I have never doctored a box cake and I was not sure how it would come out. This was awesome. I read others' reviews before I made it and decided to try the recipe as written. I had no problems with it at all. The only things I changed were that I used a dark chocolate fudge mix, canola oil instead of vegetable, coffee in for water, and a non dairy sour cream substitute since I can't eat dairy, but this was excellent! The fact that it is fast to assemble also was a huge plus! It is definitely a keeper and I will be sending it on through my recipe exchange. Yay for new favorite cake recipes!!! :)

Update: Made this w/a butter cake mix and a small package of instant vanilla with 1tsp vanilla extract added, left out the choco chips and frosted w/dark chocolate frosting, yum! Love how versatile the recipe is. I may try a german chocolate next, coconut in the batter sounds good :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe exactly for a friend's birthday cake and it was delicious! Definitely intended for chocoholics though.  Took about 55 min - 1 hr to bake. Allow plenty of time to cool as instructed because it's very soft and hard to remove from the pan without breaking.  I made it in a cake pan instead of a bundt pan because I wanted to do a stencil on top with powdered sugar.  Be forewarned that if you use a regular cake pan, it needs to be bigger than 9 in. because the cake + pudding mixes make the cake rise a LOT.  I used a 9 in. pan and had enough batter left over for 12 cupcakes!  I wouldn't recommend using a glaze or it might be too sweet.  This was perfect with a dusting of powdered sugar. Everyone went back for seconds!

This is by far the best chocolate cake recipe I've tried. (Especially with a Chocolate Fudge Frosting!). region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderful recipe.  I topped it with the Satiny Chocolate Glaze.  I made cupcakes on the 2nd time through, and they only had to bake about 22 min.  I hadn't had a problem with too much oil when baking in a Bundt pan, but there was definitely too much oil for the cupcakes, so next time I'll cut it in half.  It yields about 34 cupcakes, filled halfway.  I used strawberry cake mix, white choc. pudding and white choc. chips, and after removing from the oven I sprinkled about 10 white choc. chips on top of each cupcake, let them melt and then smeared them around.  Very good!

text:
this is the best chocolate cake ever. however, every time i have made it, the edges have started to harden by the time the middle has set, and i have to cut off the lower outer rim/corner of each cake round. i've experimented with tweaking the temperature/cook time to avoid this but have not been successful. but this has not stopped me from making this cake many times!! most recently, i cut the cake rounds in half horizontally then layered with "Chocolate Torte" frosting (from the site) and sliced strawberries to make a monstrously rich, amazing 4 layered behemoth of a cake that was SO good even my boyfriend's friends (who hate me with a passion) couldn't help but compliment it :)

text:
This is my "go to" cake, my husband's favorite! It stays so moist and flavorful. Make sure you use instant pudding instead of the kind you cook. I set aside some of the chocolate chips and zap in the microwave in a ziploc bag for a few seconds. Then I snip a corner, and voila! Instant drizzle topping. I then sprinkle a little powdered sugar, and it turns into a fancy dessert.

text:
Simply perfect, just as it is. Have made about 20 of these since finding the recipe. I use cheapo pudding and chocolate chips and it makes no difference in the taste.  I melt about a 1/3 can of store-bought chocolate frosting (I know, the horror!) and melt it in the microwave, then pour over cooled cake as a glaze.  Lovely presentation... Also have used red velvet cake recipe a number of times, then used a cream cheese frosting glaze topped with a chocolate glaze (both store bought and the rest was used for something else...).  I've taken the red velvet cake with the black/white frosting to events and people go wild over the stunning presentation...

This cake is excellent. It was very moist and per previous reviews it tasted nothing like eggs. It was very rich and chocolatey. I made it exactly as written except I used miniature chocolate chips. I will definitely be making this again. I think next time I might try it in two 9 inch pans and put a filling in between. text:
This cake was good, but a little too much for me. I actually would've only rated it three stars, but my mother-in-law raved about it to all our co-workers so I upped it one. It has a dense brownie like texture that I was not expecting.  I baked this in two round cake pans, cut them each in half and layered the cake with the sturdy whipped cream frosting recipe and topped it with raspberry sauce recipe (both from this sight). The raspberry sauce really did amazing things for this cake and I highly recommend it.

Very very yummy!  I've made this twice.  Once using the cup of oil and once with a cup of applesauce, and no one could tell the difference.  Save yourself the calories and use the apple sauce.  Everyone loves this.  It doesn't need frosting or glaze, its yummy as is, just dust with powdered sugar and its ready to go.  I find that it bakes perfectly in 45 minutes.  50 minutes is too long.  I use mini chocolate chips, it leaves it nice, moist and chocolately goodness.

text:
I followed the recipe exactly, and got a great, moist, yummy, chocolate cake! I made the cake the night before, and the icing/strawberries the day of.  I drizzled chocolate glaze, added strawberries, and served it up to about 25 people who all had big smiles and told me that it was "soooo good!". To get all the ingredients for this and the Satiny Glaze Icing (http://tinyurl.com/26v26lx) was about $18.00 - which includes a small bottle of Kayro Light Corn Syrup, 1/2 dozen eggs, a small box of strawberries, plus all the other ingredients listed. I say this because it truly is a great cake, and definitely the best (semi) homemade chocolate cake I've had - but not the best cake in general (there is just something about truly made from scratch cakes that can't be beat).  My husband really liked it - he said it tasted like we could have bought the cake at a bakery and would have ended up paying WAY more for it!  And for that reason, and the fact that it is SO easy, I will definitely keep it in my recipe box for friends who love chocolate! I didn't know if it would end up being too chocolaty for some people at the bday party, so I added the strawberries, thinking that that would add some fruity relief.  I think it did (and who doesn't love chocolate and strawberries?!).   My hubby said that next time, nix the chocolate glaze because it might just be a little too much, but to try drizzling some raspberry sauce and sprinkling it with some powdered sugar - which I will definitely do.

84
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
396
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/69415.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used mini chocolate chips and baked it in a 9 by 13 pan, then topped it with a boiled peanut butter icing.  The resulting cake was irresistible and got even better as it sat- we finished it in 5 days and it was honestly tastier on the last day than the first.  The cake was very moist, dense and chocolaty, and the peanut butter flavor went with it beautifully.  I heartily recommend using peanut butter frosting (or a boiled peanut butter icing) on this.  Next time I'm actually going to try using yogurt instead of sour cream and cut way back on the oil (possibly subbing applesauce for some of it) because the amount of fat and calories in this cake is obscene, even if it is tasty!

This recipe was pretty simple and kept its shape in the bundt pan when removed.  However, I do not really care for cakes made with boxed mix.  They never have a really dense and rich taste like the homemade cakes. This cake had a lot of high reviews, so I thought it might be different.  But, it just tasted like spongy boxed cake mix with loads of chocolate chips.  It did not transform the ingredients into anything than what they were.

I served this with our Mother's Day meal! DIVINE! After going through 100+ reviews, I only made 1 major change: used 1/2 cup oil instead of 1 cup. I used a Devil's Food Mix. Instead of chocolate chips, I cut up 3 large dark chocolate bars into 1/4"-1/2" pieces. (50% or higher cacao) The women in my family were oh so happy! I covered the cake in the Satiny Chocolate Glaze from this site. Rich and wonderful!

This cake was soo delicious. Even people who prefer vanilla cake loved this! I did use mini chocolate chips and they settled throughout the entire cake. This doesn't need any icing or glaze. It's perfect as is! Dusting with powdered sugar for presentation was all I did. I took this to a family party and everyone loved this more than store bought cake. I actually prefer this to brownies and I'm a brownie lover. The cake is rich and dense but so addicting. The chocolate chips are a delightful gooey surprise in this cake and the rich deep notes of chocolate are unforgettable.

text:
Ok..First off, this is probably getting 5 stars by so many people because it is kinda hard to mess up a box cake. So, keep in mind that it "is" a box cake, therefore if you generaly like box cakes, then you will probably give this a 4-5 star rating because of the few simple changes to make it a little better. It is a good cake. I will make it again with one change. Rather than coating the pan with oil, I will use Crisco non-stick Buterry Spray. I took one star away because this cake is similar to a pudding cake, and the recipe for the Thick'n Fudgey Tripple Chocolate Pudding Cake is amazingly better! I took another star away because of the oil taste on the outside of the cake.

text:
Well, for someone that NEVER uses cake mixes, my 10 yr. old daughter coerced me into making this for her daddy's birthday.  We were NOT disappointed!!  I LOVE, LOVE, LOVE !!!!! this cake! It is the exact type of fudgy, dense, super chocolatey cake we were looking for!  We baked in 2  9 inch round pans, as we don't ahve a bundt pan.  It took about 1 hr. and 10 mins. and rose high above the edge-could have made a 4 layer cake!!  We followed recipe, except using 3/4 cup of oil.  Topped with Satiny chocolate glaze from this site and chocolate covered strawberries, chocolate curls, whipped cream AND Hershey's kisses for a superb presentation!! (remember, this is a 10 year old's idea; you can never have TOO much chocolate!!)  Will ABSOLUTLEY make this our go-to chocolate cake and throw the old recipe in the garbage!!  Thanks so much for a great recipe!!

OK, this is ridiculous.  This has got to be the best chocolate cake ever!  I made (as stated in recipe) using mini choc chips. text:
I will never ever make another chocolate cake recipe again!  This is the only recipe I will ever make!  It's chocolately, moist and just down right delicious.  This cake doesn't even require frosting but I used the "Satiny Chocolate Glaze" recipe and it gave it such an added bonus.  After reading several reviews I altered a few things:  I reduced the oil to 1/2 cup, reduced chocolate chips to 1 3/4 cups and I also added 1/3 cup milk.  This recipe is so incredibly easy and the best part is it appears you spent hours making it because it comes out so beautifully in a bundt pan.

text:
This is an awesome cake!  It is so easy to make and soooo yummy!  I made it for my son's 2nd birthday.  Used a 9x13, followed the recipe exactly, baked it 45 minutes and that was perfect.  Cooled the cake for about 20 minutes, then microwaved a can of store bought icing 1 minute, stirred it really good and then poured over the cake and spread it around.  When it cooled it was like the chocolate glaze on a doughnut.  Everyone at the party absolutely loved this cake.  They actually couldn't believe that I had made it!  My children usually only eat the icing off of cakes and leave the cake part, but they ate every bite of this cake and asked for more.  Every time my 2 year old took a bite, he said "MMMMMM!"  Will definitely keep on making this cake!  Thanks for the recipe!
